Maximum Likelihood Estimation in Gaussian Process Regression is Ill-Posed

\nameToni Karvonen \emailtoni.karvonen@helsinki.fi
\addrDepartment of Mathematics and Statistics
University of Helsinki
PL 56 (Pietari Kalmin katu 5)
00014 Helsingin yliopisto, Finland \AND\nameChris J. Oates \emailchris.oates@ncl.ac.uk
\addrSchool of Mathematics, Statistics and Physics
Newcastle University
Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom
Abstract

Gaussian process regression underpins countless academic and industrial applications of machine learning and statistics, with maximum likelihood estimation routinely used to select appropriate parameters for the covariance kernel. However, it remains an open problem to establish the circumstances in which maximum likelihood estimation is well-posed, that is, when the predictions of the regression model are insensitive to small perturbations of the data. This article identifies scenarios where the maximum likelihood estimator fails to be well-posed, in that the predictive distributions are not Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distance. These failure cases occur in the noiseless data setting, for any Gaussian process with a stationary covariance function whose lengthscale parameter is estimated using maximum likelihood. Although the failure of maximum likelihood estimation is part of Gaussian process folklore, these rigorous theoretical results appear to be the first of their kind. The implication of these negative results is that well-posedness may need to be assessed post-hoc, on a case-by-case basis, when maximum likelihood estimation is used to train a Gaussian process model.

Keywords: Gaussian processes, maximum likelihood estimation, ill-posedness, stationary kernels

1 Introduction

Gaussian process regression is a popular tool used to construct a predictive model for a response variable as a function of one or more covariates of interest. As a strict generalisation of classical linear regression, and with the support of production-level software, Gaussian process regression has found myriad applications in both the academic and industrial contexts. The success of Gaussian process regression, both in terms of predictive performance and quality of uncertainty quantification, is contingent on the use of a suitable covariance kernel K𝐾K for the Gaussian process model. This is often achieved by choosing K𝐾K from a parametric set {Kθ}θ∈Θsubscriptsubscript𝐾𝜃𝜃Θ\{K_{\theta}\}_{\theta\in\Theta} of candidate covariance kernels, with the parameter θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta being selected based on the training data set. The predictive performance of Gaussian processes is well-understood in a variety of asymptotic settings (e.g., Stein, 1999; Anderes, 2010; van der Vaart and van Zanten, 2011; Bachoc et al., 2017; Karvonen et al., 2020). However, not much is known about the non-asymptotic setting when θ𝜃\theta is estimated from a training data set. In particular, it is an open problem to understand when the predictions from a Gaussian process model are well-posed, in the sense that the predictions of the model are either continuous in the training data set or insensitive to small perturbations of the training data set. Theoretical understanding of well-posedness is urgently needed to support the use of Gaussian process regression in sensitive applications, such as in mine gas safety monitoring (Dong, 2012), malicious maritime activity detection (Kowalska and Peel, 2012), and climate modelling (Revell et al., 2018), where the reliability and robustness of predictions is critical.

Several methods exist to estimate θ𝜃\theta, including maximum likelihood estimation (Mardia and Marshall, 1984), maximum a posteriori estimation (e.g., Cunningham et al., 2008), cross-validation (Geisser and Eddy, 1979), Bayesian inference (MacKay, 1992), kernel flows (Chen et al., 2021), and various bespoke approaches, for example when θ𝜃\theta are the parameters of a neural network in a deep kernel (Wilson et al., 2016). Among these, maximum likelihood estimators θMLsubscript𝜃ML\theta_{\textup{ML}} are arguably most widely used, for example being the default approach in Gaussian process software (Rasmussen and Nickisch, 2010; Pedregosa et al., 2011; Roustant et al., 2012; GPy, since 2012; Matthews et al., 2017). In addition to statistics and machine learning, maximum likelihood is also occasionally used in the applied mathematical literature to construct a kernel interpolant; see Fasshauer and McCourt (2015, Section 14.3) and Cavoretto (2021) for recent examples. Compared to other approaches, maximum likelihood is attractive due to the absence of any additional degrees of freedom (e.g., cross-validation requires a choice for how data are partitioned) and the possibility for automatic gradient-based optimisation.

Suppose that the data are modelled as being generated by a Gaussian process defined by a mean function m𝑚m and a positive-definite covariance kernel Kθsubscript𝐾𝜃K_{\theta}. For a noiseless training data set Y=(y1,…,yn)∈ℝn𝑌subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛Y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}, associated to a set X𝑋X of distinct covariates x1,…,xn∈ℝdsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, a maximum likelihood estimator θMLsubscript𝜃ML\theta_{\textup{ML}} of θ𝜃\theta satisfies

θML∈arg​minθ∈Θ⁡ℓ​(θ∣Y)​ with ​ℓ​(θ∣Y)=Ym𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Ym+log​detKθ​(X,X),subscript𝜃MLsubscriptargmin𝜃Θℓconditional𝜃𝑌 with ℓconditional𝜃𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋\theta_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell(\theta\mid Y)\>\>\text{ with }\>\>\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X), (1.1)

where Kθ​(X,X)=(Kθ​(xi,xj))i,j=1n∈ℝn×nsubscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐾𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝑖𝑗1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛K_{\theta}(X,X)=(K_{\theta}(x_{i},x_{j}))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} is the positive-definite covariance matrix and Ym=(yi−m​(xi))i=1n∈ℝnsubscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑚subscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛Y_{m}=(y_{i}-m(x_{i}))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. See Stein (1999, Section 6.4) or Rasmussen and Williams (2006, Section 5.4.1). Despite the simple form of the optimisation problem (1.1), there is only limited understanding of the behaviour of θMLsubscript𝜃ML\theta_{\textup{ML}} in the deterministic interpolation regime, where the data yi=f​(xi)subscript𝑦𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}=f(x_{i}) are, in truth, generated from a fixed but unknown function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. An important open problem is to understand the behaviour of θMLsubscript𝜃ML\theta_{\textup{ML}} in terms of the data-generating function f𝑓f and the set of covariates, and the implications of this behaviour for predictions produced by the Gaussian process model.

The deterministic interpolation regime represents a simple but important instance of Gaussian process regression widely used in, for example, emulation of computer experiments (Sacks et al., 1989; Kennedy and O’Hagan, 2002), probabilistic numerical computation (Diaconis, 1988; Cockayne et al., 2019; Hennig et al., 2022), and Bayesian optimisation (Snoek et al., 2012). However, this regime is challenging to analyse, and results concerning maximum likelihood estimation appear limited to the asymptotic analyses. Xu and Stein (2017); Karvonen et al. (2020); and Wang (2021) exploited a closed form for the maximum likelihood estimator of a scale parameter (i.e., θ={σ}𝜃𝜎\theta=\{\sigma\} and Kθ=σ2​Ksubscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝜎2𝐾K_{\theta}=\sigma^{2}K) to analyse its behaviour as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty in the fixed domain setting where the covariates {xi}i=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{\infty} are dense in a compact subset of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. In a similar manner, Karvonen et al. (2019) analysed maximum likelihood estimation of the scale and lengthscale parameters (i.e., θ={σ,λ}𝜃𝜎𝜆\theta=\{\sigma,\lambda\} and Kθ​(x,x′)=σ2​K​(x/λ,x′/λ)subscript𝐾𝜃𝑥superscript𝑥′superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑥𝜆superscript𝑥′𝜆K_{\theta}(x,x^{\prime})=\sigma^{2}K(x/\lambda,x^{\prime}/\lambda)) for a particular non-stationary Ornstein–Uhlenbeck process, while Karvonen (2023) obtained asymptotic lower bounds on estimates of the smoothness parameter of the Matérn model. The non-asymptotic behaviour of maximum likelihood estimation in the deterministic interpolation regime has yet to be studied.

1.1 Contributions

The principal contributions of this work are to demonstrate how the concept of well-posedness can be applied to Gaussian process interpolation and how rigorous theoretical analysis of well-posedness can be performed. We prove that, in the deterministic interpolation regime, maximum likelihood estimation of a lengthscale parameter can fail to be well-posed. We emphasise that this is a non-asymptotic (i.e., the number n𝑛n of observations is kept fixed) result, in contrast to earlier work, and is based on the observation that the maximum likelihood estimate λMLsubscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} of a lengthscale parameter λ𝜆\lambda is infinite if the observations differ from the prior mean function by a constant vertical shift.

To be more precise, consider a Gaussian process with prior mean function m𝑚m and stationary covariance function of the form

Kλ​(x,y)=Φ​(x−yλ) for x,y∈ℝd,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦𝜆 for 𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x-y}{\lambda}\bigg{)}\quad\text{ for }\quad x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, (1.2)

where the lengthscale parameter λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 determines the spatial correlation distance of the resulting Gaussian random field. If the function Φ:ℝd→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is continuous, the covariance function (1.2) tends pointwise to the constant Φ​(0)Φ0\Phi(0) as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. Thus, if the data are approximately shifted from the mean function m𝑚m by a constant, it is intuitive that a large value will be taken by the maximum likelihood estimate λMLsubscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}. It is rigorously proven in this article (see Theorem 2.3) that if (a) n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2 is fixed, (b) the function ΦΦ\Phi in (1.2) satisfies certain mild regularity conditions, and (c) there is a constant c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R} such that the data are m𝑚m-constant in that

yi=m​(xi)+c for i=1,…,n,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖𝑚subscript𝑥𝑖𝑐 for 𝑖1…𝑛y_{i}=m(x_{i})+c\quad\text{ for }\quad i=1,\ldots,n, (1.3)

then λML=∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty. This result can be viewed as a generalisation of the simple fact that maximum likelihood estimation fails if the data are fully explained by the prior mean: if yi=m​(xi)subscript𝑦𝑖𝑚subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}=m(x_{i}) for every i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n, the first term of ℓ​(λ∣Y)ℓconditional𝜆𝑌\ell(\lambda\mid Y) in (1.1) is zero and thus the estimate of λ𝜆\lambda must be infinite because Kλ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋K_{\lambda}(X,X) tends to a singular matrix if and only if λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. From λML=∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty it follows that the pointwise predictions produced by the fitted Gaussian process model assign all probability to a single point (see Theorem 2.6). This phenomenon is undesirable, as it is not reasonable to claim infinite precision from a finite data set (which could, in this case, involve as few as n=2𝑛2n=2 values being observed). Secondly, we prove that if the data are not m𝑚m-constant, then λML<∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}<\infty so that the predictive distributions are non-degenerate. Using these results we show in Section 2.4 that maximum likelihood estimation is not well-posed in general, in the sense that the resulting predictive distributions are not Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distance, which means that predictive inference can be sensitive to small perturbations of the data set.111Note that this notion of well-posedness of a parameter estimation method is stronger than that of its robustness, defined by Gu et al. (2018, Section 3) essentially as the impossibility of obtaining a singular covariance matrix.

A constant mean shift in (1.3) is not a pathological case in the deterministic interpolation context, though it does highlight one sense in which mathematical analysis may be easier when the data are assumed to come from a stochastic process, since a constant mean shift may be neglected as a measure zero event in that setting. For example, Gaussian process regression has been used to explore discrepancy between computer models (Brevault et al., 2020), where a constant mean shift between the output of two computer models for the same phenomenon could reasonably be expected. Similarly, in probabilistic numerical computation one could encounter a constant mean shift (e.g., when modelling an integrand in Bayesian cubature, if that integrand is in fact constant; Briol et al., 2019), or in applications of Bayesian optimisation, where the data are obtained in a region where the objective function is constant. The role of this article is therefore to highlight an important failure mode of maximum likelihood estimation in Gaussian process interpolation and, in doing so, to underscore the need for an improved theoretical understanding of parameter estimation in general.

It would be tempting to attribute these failings to the simplicity of the maximum likelihood estimator and the modelling choices that we consider, for surely something more sophisticated ought to render the problem well-posed. Section 3 demonstrates that there may not exist an easy solution in the deterministic interpolation regime, at least if the tractability of a Gaussian process model is to be retained. Namely, we prove the following extensions:

  1. (i)

    A certain cross-validation estimator of the scale parameter shares the undesirable property of producing infinite lengthscale estimates when the data are m𝑚m-constant.

  2. (ii)

    Inclusion of a parametric prior mean function, which too is estimated from the data (i.e., as in universal kriging), does not prevent ill-posedness.

  3. (iii)

    Simultaneous maximum likelihood estimation of the scale and lengthscale parameters does not prevent ill-posedness.

What does guarantee well-posedness is the inclusion of a regularisation or a nugget term, which corresponds to an assumption by the user that the data are corrupted by additive Gaussian noise. It is intuitive that the maximum likelihood estimator should be more well-behaved if the data-generating process is noisy as it may be merely by chance that the data set is m𝑚m-constant. Less intuitive is the numerical evidence in Section 4.1, which indicates that λMLsubscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} is infinite even in the regularised setting as long as the regularisation term is sufficiently large. A possible interpretation of this observation is that for sufficiently large assumed noise level any data could have been plausibly generated by a constant mean shift of the prior mean. The use of regularisation can hardly be considered a proper solution to ill-posedness because the interpolation property of the conditional process, desirable in many applications, is lost and an influential degree of freedom is introduced. As demonstrated in Section 4.2, another option for guaranteeing that the lengthscale estimates are always finite is to place a hyperprior on the lengthscale and use maximum a posteriori estimation. However, because the hyperprior determines the estimator, this approach is rather arbitrary and does not lend itself well to automation in software.

Most of our results apply to Matérn-type covariance functions whose Fourier transforms decay polynomially (see Assumption 2.2). Section 5 discusses generalisations of this Fourier assumption, lengthscale estimation for product kernels, and the use of general linear information, such as derivative data. Our proofs are predominantly based on reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) techniques and approximation theory in Sobolev spaces. Complete proofs are relegated to Section 7. No familiarity with RKHSs or Sobolev spaces is required to understand the statements of our main results and, outside the proofs, it is only in Section 5 that these concepts are used. Practical and theoretical implications of our results are discussed in Section 6.

1.2 Related Literature

For fixed kernel parameters θ𝜃\theta, the mathematical properties of Gaussian process interpolation as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty can be deduced from the equivalent perspective of optimal interpolation in an RKHS. See Fasshauer (2011); Scheuerer et al. (2013); and Kanagawa et al. (2018) for reviews on this equivalence. The setting where the data-generating function f𝑓f is randomised has received considerable attention and a large number of results have been obtained. Consistency and asymptotic normality results for maximum likelihood estimation of scale and lengthscale parameters can be found in, for example, Ying (1991); Zhang (2004); Loh (2005); Du et al. (2009); Anderes (2010); Kaufman and Shaby (2013); Bachoc (2013); and Bevilacqua et al. (2019). The use of maximum likelihood to estimate smoothness parameters (i.e., controlling the differentiability of the Gaussian process sample paths) has also been considered, notably by Szabó et al. (2015); Knapik et al. (2016); Chen et al. (2021); and Karvonen (2023). A well known issue with maximum likelihood estimation occurs when θ𝜃\theta is non-identifiable, as can happen when one attempts to simultaneously estimate scale, lengthscale, and smoothness parameters in the Matérn covariance model (Zhang, 2004). However, a lack of identifiability does not affect the predictions produced by the model or the combinations of parameters that can be identified (the so-called microergodic parameters). These related works, whilst providing useful insight and powerful theoretical tools and techniques, do not apply in the non-asymptotic deterministic interpolation regime where θ𝜃\theta is estimated using maximum likelihood.

2 Maximum Likelihood Estimation Is Not Well-Posed

Given any function f𝑓f and a set X𝑋X of points x1,…,xnsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x_{1},\ldots,x_{n} in the domain of f𝑓f, we use f​(X)𝑓𝑋f(X) to denote the n𝑛n-vector (f​(x1),…,f​(xn))𝑓subscript𝑥1…𝑓subscript𝑥𝑛(f(x_{1}),\ldots,f(x_{n})). All vectors in this article are to be understood to be in column format.

2.1 Gaussian Process Interpolation

In Gaussian process interpolation, the data are modelled as discrete and noiseless observations from a Gaussian process sample path. A Gaussian process fGP∼GP​(m,K)similar-tosubscript𝑓GPGP𝑚𝐾f_{\textup{GP}}\sim\mathrm{GP}(m,K) on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} is a stochastic process characterised by a mean function m:ℝd→ℝ:𝑚→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝm\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} and a covariance kernel K:ℝd×ℝd→ℝ:𝐾→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑ℝK\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}:

𝔼​[fGP​(x)]=m​(x) and Cov​[fGP​(x),fGP​(y)]=K​(x,y)formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓GP𝑥𝑚𝑥 and Covsubscript𝑓GP𝑥subscript𝑓GP𝑦𝐾𝑥𝑦\mathbb{E}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x)]=m(x)\quad\text{ and }\quad\mathrm{Cov}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x),f_{\textup{GP}}(y)]=K(x,y)

for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Let K​(X,X)=(K​(xi,xj))i,j=1n∈ℝn×n𝐾𝑋𝑋superscriptsubscript𝐾subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗𝑖𝑗1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛K(X,X)=(K(x_{i},x_{j}))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}. That fGPsubscript𝑓GPf_{\textup{GP}} is Gaussian means that all its finite-dimensional distributions are normally distributed, which is to say that

fGP​(X)∼N​(m​(X),K​(X,X))similar-tosubscript𝑓GP𝑋N𝑚𝑋𝐾𝑋𝑋f_{\textup{GP}}(X)\sim\mathrm{N}(m(X),K(X,X))

for any finite set of points X⊂ℝd𝑋superscriptℝ𝑑X\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}. Throughout this article the covariance kernel is assumed to be (strictly) positive-definite, which means that

∑i=1n∑j=1nai​aj​K​(xi,xj)>0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗𝐾subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗0\sum_{i=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{i}a_{j}K(x_{i},x_{j})>0 (2.1)

for any n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}, any non-zero vector a=(a1,…,an)𝑎subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛a=(a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}), and any distinct points xi∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. This implies that the covariance matrix K​(X,X)𝐾𝑋𝑋K(X,X) is positive-definite and non-singular if X𝑋X consists of distinct points. A covariance kernel is stationary if there is a function Φ:ℝd→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} such that

K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y) for all x,y∈ℝd.formulae-sequence𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦 for all 𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y)\quad\text{ for all }\quad x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (2.2)

If ΦΦ\Phi is to yield a positive-definite covariance kernel, it is necessary that Φ​(0)>0Φ00\Phi(0)>0 because otherwise the condition (2.1) fails for n=1𝑛1n=1. For the purposes of this article, the Matérn kernels constitute the most important class of stationary covariance functions. Let σ𝜎\sigma, λ𝜆\lambda, and ν𝜈\nu be positive. A Matérn kernel with scale σ𝜎\sigma, lengthscale λ𝜆\lambda, and smoothness ν𝜈\nu is given by

K​(x,y)=σ2​21−νΓ​(ν)​(2​ν​∥x−y∥λ)ν​𝒦ν​(2​ν​∥x−y∥λ),𝐾𝑥𝑦superscript𝜎2superscript21𝜈Γ𝜈superscript2𝜈delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦𝜆𝜈subscript𝒦𝜈2𝜈delimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦𝜆K(x,y)=\sigma^{2}\frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}^{\nu}\mathcal{K}_{\nu}\bigg{(}\frac{\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}}{\lambda}\bigg{)}, (2.3)

where ΓΓ\Gamma is the Gamma function and 𝒦νsubscript𝒦𝜈\mathcal{K}_{\nu} the modified Bessel function of the second kind.

Suppose that a noiseless training data set Y=(y1,…,yn)∈ℝn𝑌subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛Y=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n} associated to a set X𝑋X of distinct covariates x1,…,xn∈ℝdsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} has been obtained and let Ym=Y−m​(X)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑌𝑚𝑋Y_{m}=Y-m(X). P​(x,y)2=Cov​[fGP​(x),fGP​(y)∣Y]=K​(x,y)−K​(x,X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​K​(X,y).𝑃superscript𝑥𝑦2Covsubscript𝑓GP𝑥conditionalsubscript𝑓GP𝑦𝑌𝐾𝑥𝑦𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1𝐾𝑋𝑦P(x,y)^{2}=\mathrm{Cov}[f_{\textup{GP}}(x),f_{\textup{GP}}(y)\mid Y]=K(x,y)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}K(X,y). (2.5)

We use the simplified notation P​(x,x)2=P​(x)2𝑃superscript𝑥𝑥2𝑃superscript𝑥2P(x,x)^{2}=P(x)^{2} for the conditional variance. It is often convenient, especially in our proofs, to use the function

s​(x)=K​(x,X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​Ym𝑠𝑥𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚s(x)=K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} (2.6)

and write the conditional mean as μ=m+s𝜇𝑚𝑠\mu=m+s. The assumption that there is no noise means that we are in the deterministic interpolation regime where μ𝜇\mu is an interpolant to the data, which is to say that μ​(xi)=yi𝜇subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\mu(x_{i})=y_{i} and P​(xi)=0𝑃subscript𝑥𝑖0P(x_{i})=0 for every i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n. Crucially, this assumption allows us to leverage well known equivalences, reviewed in Section 7.1, between Gaussian process interpolation and kernel-based minimum-norm interpolation (e.g., Scheuerer et al., 2013; Kanagawa et al., 2018).

2.2 Maximum Likelihood Estimation

Maximum likelihood estimation is the most common method used to select parameters θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta of a parametrised covariance kernel Kθsubscript𝐾𝜃K_{\theta}. Under the Gaussian process model GP​(m,Kθ)GP𝑚subscript𝐾𝜃\mathrm{GP}(m,K_{\theta}), the probability density function of the data Y𝑌Y given θ𝜃\theta is (e.g., Rasmussen and Williams, 2006, Section 5.4.1)

1det(2​π​Kθ​(X,X))1/2​exp⁡(−12​Ym𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Ym).1superscript2𝜋subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋1212superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚\frac{1}{\det(2\pi K_{\theta}(X,X))^{1/2}}\exp\bigg{(}\!\!-\frac{1}{2}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\bigg{)}. (2.7)

Maximising (2.7) over ΘΘ\Theta is equivalent to minimising

ℓ​(θ∣Y)=Ym𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Ym+log​detKθ​(X,X),ℓconditional𝜃𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X), (2.8)

which we call the modified log-likelihood function, being the log-likelihood function up to subtraction and multiplication by negative constants. That is, any maximum likelihood estimate (which may not be unique if ℓℓ\ell is multimodal) of θ𝜃\theta satisfies

θML∈arg​minθ∈Θ⁡ℓ​(θ∣Y).subscript𝜃MLsubscriptargmin𝜃Θℓconditional𝜃𝑌\theta_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell(\theta\mid Y).

The two terms that comprise the modified log-likelihood function (2.8) are usually called the (negative) data-fit and model complexity terms, respectively. Throughout the article we use subscripts to denote that various quantities depend on the kernel parameters. For example, the parameter-dependent conditional mean and covariance are

μθ​(x)subscript𝜇𝜃𝑥\displaystyle\mu_{\theta}(x) =m​(x)+Kθ​(x,X)𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Ym,absent𝑚𝑥subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚\displaystyle=m(x)+K_{\theta}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m},
Pθ​(x,y)2subscript𝑃𝜃superscript𝑥𝑦2\displaystyle P_{\theta}(x,y)^{2} =Kθ​(x,y)−Kθ​(x,X)𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Kθ​(X,y).absentsubscript𝐾𝜃𝑥𝑦subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑦\displaystyle=K_{\theta}(x,y)-K_{\theta}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}K_{\theta}(X,y).

We are interested in estimation of the lengthscale parameter λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 which parametrises any stationary kernel of the form (2.2) as

Kλ​(x,y)=Φ​(x−yλ)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦𝜆K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\Phi\bigg{(}\frac{x-y}{\lambda}\bigg{)}

and determines the spatial correlation distance of the resulting Gaussian process (see Figure 1). A maximum likelihood estimate of λ𝜆\lambda therefore satisfies

λML∈arg​minλ>0⁡ℓ​(λ∣Y)=arg​minλ>0⁡{Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym+log​detKλ​(X,X)}.subscript𝜆MLsubscriptargmin𝜆0ℓconditional𝜆𝑌subscriptargmin𝜆0superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋\lambda_{\textup{ML}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\big{\{}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)\big{\}}.

Specifically, we are interested in rigorously proving that λML=∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty in certain cases. As λ𝜆\lambda increases, the kernel Kλsubscript𝐾𝜆K_{\lambda} tends pointwise to Φ​(0)Φ0\Phi(0), which is not positive-definite, and the covariance matrices in the predictive mean (2.4) and covariance (2.5) become singular if n>1𝑛1n>1. However, the limits limλ→∞μλsubscript→𝜆subscript𝜇𝜆\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda} and limλ→∞Pλ​(x,y)2subscript→𝜆subscript𝑃𝜆superscript𝑥𝑦2\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}(x,y)^{2} do exist for most commonly used kernels, such as Matérns and the Gaussian, and it is in this limiting sense that one should interpret the conditional moments when λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty. This is discussed in more detail in Section 2.3.

Our results on the behaviour of λMLsubscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} (and, later, other estimators of λ𝜆\lambda) show that Gaussian process interpolation fails, producing degenerate predictive distributions, when the data are m𝑚m-constant and the function ΦΦ\Phi has a polynomially decaying Fourier transform.

Definition 2.1 (Constant data)

Given a mean function m𝑚m, we say that the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant if there is a constant c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R} such that

Ym=Y−m​(X)=(c,…,c)∈ℝn.subscript𝑌𝑚𝑌𝑚𝑋𝑐…𝑐superscriptℝ𝑛Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

Let f^​(ξ)=∫ℝdg​(x)​e−i​ξ𝖳​x​d⁡x^𝑓𝜉subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑔𝑥superscripteisuperscript𝜉𝖳𝑥d𝑥\widehat{f}(\xi)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g(x)\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i}\xi^{\mathsf{T}}x}\operatorname{d\!}x denote the Fourier transform of an integrable function f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. We use the following assumption on the rate of decay of the Fourier transform of a stationary kernel.

Assumption 2.2 (Stationary Sobolev kernel)

There are a continuous and integrable function Φ:ℝd→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} and constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2>0subscript𝐶20C_{2}>0 and α>d/2𝛼𝑑2\alpha>d/2 such that K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and

C1​(1+∥ξ∥2)−α≤Φ^​(ξ)≤C2​(1+∥ξ∥2)−αsubscript𝐶1superscript1superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜉2𝛼^Φ𝜉subscript𝐶2superscript1superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜉2𝛼C_{1}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{-\alpha}\leq\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\leq C_{2}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{-\alpha} (2.9)

for all ξ∈ℝd𝜉superscriptℝ𝑑\xi\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

If d=1𝑑1d=1 and Assumption 2.2 holds for α=p+1∈ℕ𝛼𝑝1ℕ\alpha=p+1\in\mathbb{N}, the kernel is p𝑝p times differentiable in that the derivative

∂2​p∂xp​∂yp​K​(x,y)|x=0y=0=(−1)p​Φ2​p​(0)evaluated-atsuperscript2𝑝superscript𝑥𝑝superscript𝑦𝑝𝐾𝑥𝑦𝑥0𝑦0superscript1𝑝superscriptΦ2𝑝0\frac{\partial^{2p}}{\partial x^{p}\partial y^{p}}K(x,y)\Bigr{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}x=0\\ y=0\end{subarray}}=(-1)^{p}\Phi^{2p}(0)

exists. As a consequence, the process fGP∼GP​(m,K)similar-tosubscript𝑓GPGP𝑚𝐾f_{\textup{GP}}\sim\mathrm{GP}(m,K) is p𝑝p times mean-square differentiable (Stein, 1999, Section 2.4). That a kernel satisfying (2.9) is called a Sobolev kernel is because its RKHS is norm-equivalent to the Sobolev space W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) of order α𝛼\alpha. The norm-equivalence is a crucial ingredient in several of our proofs and is reviewed, together with Sobolev spaces, in more detail in Section 7.3. One can also prove that the sample paths of fGPsubscript𝑓GPf_{\textup{GP}} are elements of certain Sobolev spaces (Scheuerer, 2011; Steinwart, 2019; Henderson, 2022). The Fourier transform of the function

Φ​(z)=σ2​21−νΓ​(ν)​(2​ν​∥z∥)ν​𝒦ν​(2​ν​∥z∥),z∈ℝd,formulae-sequenceΦ𝑧superscript𝜎2superscript21𝜈Γ𝜈superscript2𝜈delimited-∥∥𝑧𝜈subscript𝒦𝜈2𝜈delimited-∥∥𝑧𝑧superscriptℝ𝑑\Phi(z)=\sigma^{2}\frac{2^{1-\nu}}{\Gamma(\nu)}\big{(}\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}\big{)}^{\nu}\mathcal{K}_{\nu}\big{(}\sqrt{2\nu}\mathinner{\!\left\lVert z\right\rVert}\big{)},\quad z\in\mathbb{R}^{d},

which defines a Matérn kernel in (2.3), is (e.g., Stein, 1999, p. 49)

Φ^​(ξ)=σ2​Γ​(ν+d/2)πd/2​Γ​(ν)​(2​ν)ν​(2​ν+∥ξ∥2)−(ν+d/2).^Φ𝜉superscript𝜎2Γ𝜈𝑑2superscript𝜋𝑑2Γ𝜈superscript2𝜈𝜈superscript2𝜈superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜉2𝜈𝑑2\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)=\sigma^{2}\frac{\Gamma(\nu+d/2)}{\pi^{d/2}\Gamma(\nu)}(2\nu)^{\nu}\big{(}2\nu+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2}\big{)}^{-(\nu+d/2)}. (2.10)

Therefore a Matérn kernel with smoothness ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 satisfies Assumption 2.2 with α=ν+d/2𝛼𝜈𝑑2\alpha=\nu+d/2.

With these preliminaries we are ready to state the main result of this article on the behaviour of maximum likelihood estimates of λ𝜆\lambda. The result is illustrated in Figure 2.

Theorem 2.3 (Maximum likelihood estimation)

Suppose that the kernel K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. If the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant, then

limλ→∞ℓ​(λ∣Y)=−∞ and λML=∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆ℓconditional𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty. (2.11)

If the data Y𝑌Y are not m𝑚m-constant, then

limλ→∞ℓ​(λ∣Y)=∞ and λML<∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆ℓconditional𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}<\infty. (2.12)

Proof  See Section 7.4. The proof uses RKHS techniques to show that under Assumption 2.2 the data-fit term, as a function of λ𝜆\lambda, (a) is upper bounded if the data are m𝑚m-constant and (b) grows polynomially if the data are not m𝑚m-constant, while the covariance matrix tends to the matrix consisting of Φ​(0)Φ0\Phi(0)’s as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty and it can be shown that its log-determinant (i.e., the model complexity) tends to negative infinity with at most rate −log⁡λ𝜆-\log\lambda.  

Remark 2.4

It would be very interesting and useful to obtain a more quantitative version of Theorem 2.3 which would, for example, state that

λML≥g​(constm​(Y))subscript𝜆ML𝑔subscriptconst𝑚𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}\geq g(\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y)) (2.13)

for some measure constm​(Y)subscriptconst𝑚𝑌\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y) of how far Y𝑌Y are from being m𝑚m-constant (i.e., constm​(Y)=0subscriptconst𝑚𝑌0\mathrm{const}_{m}(Y)=0 if and only if Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant) and some decreasing function g:(0,∞)→ℝ:𝑔→0ℝg\colon(0,\infty)\to\mathbb{R} such that g​(r)→∞→𝑔𝑟g(r)\to\infty as r→0→𝑟0r\to 0. Unfortunately, the techniques we use to prove Theorem 2.3 are not precise enough to prove any form of (2.13).

Remark 2.5

For simplicity, suppose that m≡0𝑚0m\equiv 0 so that the data being m𝑚m-constant means that Y=(c,…,c)𝑌𝑐…𝑐Y=(c,\ldots,c) for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R}. Because the case λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty formally corresponds to a model with a constant kernel, one might be tempted to interpret Theorem 2.3 as a special case of a general theorem which would state that θMLsubscript𝜃ML\theta_{\textup{ML}} takes the value θ¯¯𝜃\bar{\theta} for which the data are fully explained by a single translate of Kθ¯subscript𝐾¯𝜃K_{\bar{\theta}}. However, there can be no such theorem. For suppose that there are θ¯∈Θ¯𝜃Θ\bar{\theta}\in\Theta and i∈{1,…,n}𝑖1…𝑛i\in\{1,\ldots,n\} such that the data could have been generated by the translate of Kθ¯subscript𝐾¯𝜃K_{\bar{\theta}} at xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. That is, Y=a​Kθ¯​(xi,X)𝑌𝑎subscript𝐾¯𝜃subscript𝑥𝑖𝑋Y=aK_{\bar{\theta}}(x_{i},X) for some a∈ℝ𝑎ℝa\in\mathbb{R}. Then

ℓ​(θ∣Y)=Y𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Y+log​detKθ​(X,X)ℓconditional𝜃𝑌superscript𝑌𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑌subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋\ell(\theta\mid Y)=Y^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X)

would have to attain its minimum at θ=θ¯𝜃¯𝜃\theta=\bar{\theta}. But because the data-fit term is non-negative and the model complexity term does not depend on the data, it is clear that a minimum can be attained at θ¯¯𝜃\bar{\theta} only by “chance” or if log​detKθ¯​(X,X)=−∞subscript𝐾¯𝜃𝑋𝑋\log\det K_{\bar{\theta}}(X,X)=-\infty, which happens only if Kθ¯​(X,X)subscript𝐾¯𝜃𝑋𝑋K_{\bar{\theta}}(X,X) is singular or, in other words, if Kθ¯subscript𝐾¯𝜃K_{\bar{\theta}} is not a valid positive-definite kernel. That is, there can be no general theorem that θML=θ¯subscript𝜃ML¯𝜃\theta_{\textup{ML}}=\bar{\theta} if it is required that Kθ¯subscript𝐾¯𝜃K_{\bar{\theta}} be a well-defined positive-definite kernel.

Next we discuss the behaviour of the conditional mean and covariance and give a precise meaning to ill-posedness of Gaussian process interpolation that we have repeatedly alluded to.

2.3 Conditional Mean and Variance in the Flat Limit

Given Theorem 2.3, the question that arises is how the conditional mean (2.4) and covariance (2.5) behave if the data are m𝑚m-constant. As the kernel becomes constant for λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty, the linear systems in the equations which define the conditional moments are singular if n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. The sensible approach is therefore to consider the limits of μλ​(x)subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥\mu_{\lambda}(x) and Pλ​(x,y)subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥𝑦P_{\lambda}(x,y) as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. This flat limit has been extensively studied during the past twenty years in the literature on radial basis function interpolation; see, for instance, Lee et al. (2015) or Barthelmé and Usevich (2021) and the references therein. Flat limits have been recently considered in the context of Gaussian process interpolation by Barthelmé et al. (2022). The conclusion of this body of research is that, under certain assumptions on the kernel and the covariate set geometry, the kernel-dependent term of the conditional mean in (2.6) tends pointwise to (a) a polynomial interpolant if the kernel is infinitely differentiable (Lee et al., 2007, Theorem 3.4) or (b) a polyharmonic spline interpolant if the kernel is finitely differentiable (Song et al., 2012, Theorem 1). Interestingly, if the data are m𝑚m-constant, we find that it is possible to present a simpler proof that is completely self-contained.

Theorem 2.6

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1. If Ym=(c,…,c)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑐…𝑐Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R}, then

limλ→∞μλ​(x)=m​(x)+c and limλ→∞|Pλ​(x,y)|=0formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥𝑚𝑥𝑐 and subscript→𝜆subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥𝑦0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+c\quad\text{ and }\quad\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mathinner{\lvert P_{\lambda}(x,y)\rvert}=0

for any x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Proof  See Section 7.5.  

Theorem 2.6 is illustrated in Figure 3. Since ΦΦ\Phi is assumed continuous in Assumption 2.2, μλ​(x)subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥\mu_{\lambda}(x) and Pλ​(x,y)subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥𝑦P_{\lambda}(x,y) are continuous functions of λ𝜆\lambda for any fixed x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} (which is proved similarly to Lemma 7.1). Therefore Theorem 2.6 justifies writing

μλ=∞​(x)=m​(x)+c and Pλ=∞​(x,y)=0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝜆𝑥𝑚𝑥𝑐 and subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥𝑦0\mu_{\lambda=\infty}(x)=m(x)+c\quad\text{ and }\quad P_{\lambda=\infty}(x,y)=0. (2.14)

2.4 Ill-Posedness

By the classical definition of Hadamard, an inference or estimation problem is well-posed if (i) a solution exists, (ii) the solution is unique, and (iii) the solution depends on continuously on the data. If these conditions are not met, the problem is ill-posed. In the Bayesian inverse problems literature, where the solution is a posterior measure, the third condition is often strengthened to a requirement that the posterior be locally Lipschitz in the data with respect to the Hellinger distance (Stuart, 2010, Section 4). One of the reasons that make Hellinger distance suitable in our context is that two distributions that are close in Hellinger distance are close also in mean and variance. However, one may also consider other probability metrics (e.g., Latz, 2020). In this section we show that prediction using Gaussian process interpolation is not well-posed in the latter Lipschitz–Hellinger sense if the lengthscale parameter is set using maximum likelihood. Bringing formal notions of well-posedness to bear on Gaussian process interpolation has not, to the best of our knowledge, previously been attempted.

Let Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} and Q2subscript𝑄2Q_{2} be two probability distributions on ℝqsuperscriptℝ𝑞\mathbb{R}^{q} that are absolutely continuous with respect a reference measure ν𝜈\nu on ℝqsuperscriptℝ𝑞\mathbb{R}^{q} and let q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2} denote their Radon–Nikodym derivatives with respect to ν𝜈\nu. The squared Hellinger distance between Q1subscript𝑄1Q_{1} and Q2subscript𝑄2Q_{2} is

dHel​(Q1,Q2)2=12​∫ℝq(q1​(x)1/2−q2​(x)1/2)2​d⁡ν​(x).subscript𝑑Helsuperscriptsubscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2212subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑞superscriptsubscript𝑞1superscript𝑥12subscript𝑞2superscript𝑥122d𝜈𝑥d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{1},Q_{2})^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{q}}\big{(}q_{1}(x)^{1/2}-q_{2}(x)^{1/2}\big{)}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\nu(x). (2.15)

The Hellinger distance does not depend on the reference measure ν𝜈\nu, which means that for distributions that admit Lebesgue density functions we may set d⁡ν​(x)=d⁡xd𝜈𝑥d𝑥\operatorname{d\!}\nu(x)=\operatorname{d\!}x. For univariate Gaussians Q1=N​(μ1,Σ1)subscript𝑄1Nsubscript𝜇1subscriptΣ1Q_{1}=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{1},\Sigma_{1}) and Q2=N​(μ2,Σ2)subscript𝑄2Nsubscript𝜇2subscriptΣ2Q_{2}=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{2},\Sigma_{2}), we have

dHel​(Q1,Q2)2=1−2​(Σ1​Σ2)1/4Σ1+Σ2​exp⁡(−(μ1−μ2)24​(Σ1+Σ2)).subscript𝑑Helsuperscriptsubscript𝑄1subscript𝑄2212superscriptsubscriptΣ1subscriptΣ214subscriptΣ1subscriptΣ2superscriptsubscript𝜇1subscript𝜇224subscriptΣ1subscriptΣ2d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{1},Q_{2})^{2}=1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(\Sigma_{1}\Sigma_{2})^{1/4}}{\sqrt{\Sigma_{1}+\Sigma_{2}}}\exp\bigg{(}\!-\frac{(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})^{2}}{4(\Sigma_{1}+\Sigma_{2})}\bigg{)}. (2.16)

Let Q​(Y)𝑄𝑌Q(Y) stand for a posterior measure given an observed data vector Y∈ℝn𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. The posterior is said to be well-posed if for every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 there exists L>0𝐿0L>0 such that

dHel​(Q​(Y),Q​(Y′))≤L​∥Y−Y′∥subscript𝑑Hel𝑄𝑌𝑄superscript𝑌′𝐿delimited-∥∥𝑌superscript𝑌′d_{\textup{Hel}}\big{(}Q(Y),Q(Y^{\prime})\big{)}\leq L\mathinner{\lVert Y-Y^{\prime}\rVert} (2.17)

for any data vectors Y,Y′∈ℝn𝑌superscript𝑌′superscriptℝ𝑛Y,Y^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} for which ∥Y−Y′∥≤εdelimited-∥∥𝑌superscript𝑌′𝜀\mathinner{\lVert Y-Y^{\prime}\rVert}\leq\varepsilon.

Let us consider the Gaussian process predictive distribution at some unobserved point x0∉Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\notin X as the posterior and set

QGP​(Y)=N​(μλML​(Y)​(x0),PλML​(Y)​(x0)2),subscript𝑄GP𝑌Nsubscript𝜇subscript𝜆ML𝑌subscript𝑥0subscript𝑃subscript𝜆ML𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑥02Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y)=\mathrm{N}(\mu_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0}),P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0})^{2}), (2.18)

where we use λML​(Y)subscript𝜆ML𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) to denote that a maximum likelihood estimate depends on the data Y𝑌Y. We may assume that λML​(Y)subscript𝜆ML𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) (or, if the modified log-likelihood function has multiple global minimum points, the largest of these) is a continuous function of the data, for otherwise predictions would not be continuous in the data, let alone Lipschitz. Let ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and let (Yk)k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘𝑘1(Y_{k})_{k=1}^{\infty} and (Yk′)k=1∞superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′𝑘1(Y_{k}^{\prime})_{k=1}^{\infty} be two data sequences which satisfy ∥Yk−Yk′∥≤εdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′𝜀\mathinner{\lVert Y_{k}-Y_{k}^{\prime}\rVert}\leq\varepsilon for every k∈ℕ𝑘ℕk\in\mathbb{N} and which converge to an m𝑚m-constant data set:

limk→∞Yk−m​(X)=limk→∞Yk′−m​(X)=(c,…,c)∈ℝnsubscript→𝑘subscript𝑌𝑘𝑚𝑋subscript→𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′𝑚𝑋𝑐…𝑐superscriptℝ𝑛\lim_{k\to\infty}Y_{k}-m(X)=\lim_{k\to\infty}Y_{k}^{\prime}-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}

for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R}. By Theorems 2.3 and 2.6 and the assumed continuity of λML​(Y)subscript𝜆ML𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y) in the data, these sequences can be selected such that

Σk≔PλML​(Yk)​(x0)2=C1​e−k and Σk′≔PλML​(Yk′)​(x0)2=C2​k−1formulae-sequence≔subscriptΣ𝑘subscript𝑃subscript𝜆MLsubscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥02subscript𝐶1superscripte𝑘≔ and superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑘′subscript𝑃subscript𝜆MLsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝑥02subscript𝐶2superscript𝑘1\Sigma_{k}\coloneqq P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y_{k})}(x_{0})^{2}=C_{1}\mathrm{e}^{-k}\quad\text{ and }\quad\Sigma_{k}^{\prime}\coloneqq P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y_{k}^{\prime})}(x_{0})^{2}=C_{2}k^{-1}

for some positive constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}. Since e−x≤1superscripte𝑥1\operatorname{e}^{-x}\leq 1 for all x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0, we get from (2.16) and (2.18) that

dHel​(QGP​(Yk),QGP​(Yk′))2≥1−2​(Σk​Σk′)1/4Σk+Σk′=1−2​(C1​C2)1/4​k−1/4​e−k/4C1​e−k+C2​k−1≥1−2​C11/4​C2−1/4​k1/4​e−k/4,subscript𝑑Helsuperscriptsubscript𝑄GPsubscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝑄GPsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′212superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑘superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑘′14subscriptΣ𝑘superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑘′12superscriptsubscript𝐶1subscript𝐶214superscript𝑘14superscripte𝑘4subscript𝐶1superscripte𝑘subscript𝐶2superscript𝑘112superscriptsubscript𝐶114superscriptsubscript𝐶214superscript𝑘14superscripte𝑘4\begin{split}d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}^{\prime}))^{2}\geq 1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(\Sigma_{k}\Sigma_{k}^{\prime})^{1/4}}{\sqrt{\smash[b]{\Sigma_{k}+\Sigma_{k}^{\prime}}}}&=1-\frac{\sqrt{2}(C_{1}C_{2})^{1/4}k^{-1/4}\mathrm{e}^{-k/4}}{\sqrt{\smash[b]{C_{1}\mathrm{e}^{-k}+C_{2}k^{-1}}}}\\ &\geq 1-\sqrt{2}\,C_{1}^{1/4}C_{2}^{-1/4}k^{1/4}\mathrm{e}^{-k/4},\end{split}

where the second term tends to zero as k→∞→𝑘k\to\infty. Therefore

dHel​(QGP​(Yk),QGP​(Yk′))→1 as k→∞formulae-sequence→subscript𝑑Helsubscript𝑄GPsubscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝑄GPsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′1 as →𝑘d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y_{k}^{\prime}))\to 1\quad\text{ as }\quad k\to\infty

even though ∥Yk−Yk′∥→0→delimited-∥∥subscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑘′0\mathinner{\lVert Y_{k}-Y_{k}^{\prime}\rVert}\to 0 as k→∞→𝑘k\to\infty. This shows that the Lipschitz condition (2.17) fails to hold when the data domain is

ℛn={Y∈ℝn:Y​ is not m-constant }⊂ℝn,superscriptℛ𝑛𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛:𝑌 is not m-constant superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{R}^{n}=\{Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,Y\text{ is not $m$-constant }\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n},

the set of data sets that are not m𝑚m-constant. That is, we have shown that the mapping QGP:ℛn→𝒫:subscript𝑄GP→superscriptℛ𝑛𝒫Q_{\textup{GP}}\colon\mathcal{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P} defined in (2.18) is not Lipschitz, where 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is the space of probability distributions on ℝℝ\mathbb{R} equipped with the Hellinger distance.

The above derivation is a consequence of the fact that, from Theorem 2.3 and the interpretation in (2.14),

PλML​(Y)​(x0)2=0subscript𝑃subscript𝜆ML𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑥020P_{\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)}(x_{0})^{2}=0

if the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant. Then for any data Y′superscript𝑌′Y^{\prime} which are not m𝑚m-constant we compute from (2.16) that

dHel​(QGP​(Y),QGP​(Y′))=1,subscript𝑑Helsubscript𝑄GP𝑌subscript𝑄GPsuperscript𝑌′1d_{\textup{Hel}}(Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y),Q_{\textup{GP}}(Y^{\prime}))=1,

which means that the predictive distribution is not continuous at any data which are m𝑚m-constant. Note that this is a purely formal computation because (2.15) and (2.16) are valid only for measures which are absolutely continuous with respect a common reference measure, which is not the case with the degenerate Gaussian predictive distribution Y𝑌Y that arises from m𝑚m-constant data and the non-degenerate Gaussian Y′superscript𝑌′Y^{\prime}. By observing that the argument above uses Theorem 2.3 only to guarantee the existence of data Y𝑌Y for which λML​(Y)=∞subscript𝜆ML𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}(Y)=\infty, we may formulate the following generic ill-posedness theorem.

Theorem 2.7 (Ill-posedness)

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1. Let λ¯:ℝn→[0,∞]:¯𝜆→superscriptℝ𝑛0\bar{\lambda}\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\to[0,\infty] be any estimator of λ𝜆\lambda and define ℛn={Y∈ℝn:λ¯​(Y)<∞}⊂ℝnsuperscriptℛ𝑛𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛:¯𝜆𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{R}^{n}=\{Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,\bar{\lambda}(Y)<\infty\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}. If there are data Y∈ℝn𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n} such that λ¯​(Y)=∞¯𝜆𝑌\bar{\lambda}(Y)=\infty (i.e., ℛn≠ℝnsuperscriptℛ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{R}^{n}\neq\mathbb{R}^{n}), then Gaussian process interpolation is ill-posed, in the sense that the predictive distribution mapping QGP:ℛn→𝒫:subscript𝑄GP→superscriptℛ𝑛𝒫Q_{\textup{GP}}\colon\mathcal{R}^{n}\to\mathcal{P} defined in (2.18) is not Lipschitz for any x0∉Xsubscript𝑥0𝑋x_{0}\notin X.

The main message of Theorem 2.7 is that a lengthscale estimator, whatever it might be, must be finite for any data in order for Gaussian process interpolation to be well-posed.

3 What Does Not Help

The Gaussian process model in Theorem 2.3 is fairly simple, having a fixed prior mean function and a single estimated hyperparameter. One might hope that additional modelling choices—or the use of an altogether different parameter estimation method—would yield a well-posed Gaussian process model. In this section we show that this is not to be for several common approaches. Each theorem in this section shows that an estimator of λ𝜆\lambda is infinite if the data are m𝑚m-constant, so that Theorem 2.7 consequently establishes that Gaussian process interpolation is ill-posed.

3.1 Cross-Validation

Leave-one-out cross-validation is a popular alternative to maximum likelihood estimation that has been shown to confer robustness when the Gaussian process model is misspecified (Bachoc, 2013). In Gaussian process interpolation the objective function that is typically used is

ℓCV​(θ∣Y)=∑k=1n[(yk−μθ,n,k​(xk)Pθ,n,k​(xk))2+log⁡[Pθ,n,k​(xk)2]],subscriptℓCVconditional𝜃𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝜇𝜃𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑃𝜃𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘2subscript𝑃𝜃𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘2\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\theta\mid Y)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\bigg{[}\bigg{(}\frac{y_{k}-\mu_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})}{P_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})}\bigg{)}^{2}+\log[P_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k})^{2}]\bigg{]}, (3.1)

where μθ,n,k=m+sθ,n,ksubscript𝜇𝜃𝑛𝑘𝑚subscript𝑠𝜃𝑛𝑘\mu_{\theta,n,k}=m+s_{\theta,n,k} and Pθ,n,ksubscript𝑃𝜃𝑛𝑘P_{\theta,n,k} denote the Gaussian process conditional mean and standard deviation functions in (2.4)–(2.6) based on data at the points X∖{xk}𝑋subscript𝑥𝑘X\setminus\{x_{k}\}; see, for example, Section 4.2 in Currin et al. (1988) or Section 5.4.1 in Rasmussen and Williams (2006). Subscripts are again used to make explicit the dependency of these functions on the kernel parameters θ𝜃\theta. Any corresponding parameter estimate θCVsubscript𝜃CV\theta_{\textup{CV}} satisfies

θCV∈arg​minθ∈Θ⁡ℓCV​(θ∣Y).subscript𝜃CVsubscriptargmin𝜃ΘsubscriptℓCVconditional𝜃𝑌\theta_{\textup{CV}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\theta\mid Y).

The cross-validation objective function (3.1) is obtained by summing negative predictive log-probabilities of yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} given data at X∖{xk}𝑋subscript𝑥𝑘X\setminus\{x_{k}\} and discarding terms which do not depend on θ𝜃\theta. Unfortunately, leave-one-out cross-validation also fails to be well-posed. This may not be surprising given that there is a close connection between maximum likelihood estimation and cross-validation (Fong and Holmes, 2020).

Theorem 3.1 (Cross-validation)

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. If the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant, then

limλ→∞ℓCV​(λ∣Y)=−∞ and λCV=∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆subscriptℓCVconditional𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆CV\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{CV}}=\infty. (3.2)

Proof  See Section 7.6. Despite the ostensibly different forms of the objective functions (2.8) and (3.1), the proof is, in consequence of Proposition 7.5, in essence all but identical to the proof of Equation 2.11 in Theorem 2.3.  

We believe that ℓCV​(λ∣Y)subscriptℓCVconditional𝜆𝑌\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y) and λCVsubscript𝜆CV\lambda_{\textup{CV}} satisfy a version of Equation 2.12 if the data are not m𝑚m-constant but have been unable to furnish a proof; see Remark 7.8.

Remark 3.2

A non-probabilistic alternative to (3.1) is to simply minimise the sum of squared leave-one-out errors (e.g., Rippa, 1999):

ℓCV​(2)​(θ∣Y)=∑k=1n(yk−μθ,n,k​(xk))2≥0 and θCV​(2)∈arg​minθ∈Θ⁡ℓCV​(2)​(θ∣Y).formulae-sequencesubscriptℓCV2conditional𝜃𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝜇𝜃𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘20 and subscript𝜃CV2subscriptargmin𝜃ΘsubscriptℓCV2conditional𝜃𝑌\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\theta\mid Y)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(y_{k}-\mu_{\theta,n,k}(x_{k}))^{2}\geq 0\quad\text{ and }\quad\theta_{\textup{CV}(2)}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\theta\mid Y).

Consider estimating the lengthscale parameter λ𝜆\lambda using this procedure. If the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant such that Ym=Y−m​(X)=(c,…,c)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑌𝑚𝑋𝑐…𝑐Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=(c,\ldots,c), it follows from Theorem 2.6 that μλ,n,ksubscript𝜇𝜆𝑛𝑘\mu_{\lambda,n,k} tends pointwise to m+c𝑚𝑐m+c as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty if K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2. Therefore

limλ→∞ℓCV​(2)​(λ∣Y)=limλ→∞∑k=1n(m​(xk)+c−μλ,n,k​(xk))2=0,subscript→𝜆subscriptℓCV2conditional𝜆𝑌subscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛superscript𝑚subscript𝑥𝑘𝑐subscript𝜇𝜆𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑘20\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\lambda\mid Y)=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{n}(m(x_{k})+c-\mu_{\lambda,n,k}(x_{k}))^{2}=0,

from which it follows that λCV​(2)=∞subscript𝜆CV2\lambda_{\textup{CV}(2)}=\infty, or at least that ℓCV​(2)​(λ∣Y)subscriptℓCV2conditional𝜆𝑌\ell_{\textup{CV}(2)}(\lambda\mid Y) has one of its minima at infinity. Therefore also this procedure is ill-posed.

3.2 Unknown Parametric Prior Mean

So far we have considered a setting where the prior mean function m𝑚m is known and fixed. But in methods such as universal kriging the mean is assumed to be an unknown element of the linear span of a finite number of basis functions, typically polynomials, and its coefficients are estimated from the data. See, for example, O’Hagan (1978) or Chapters 3 and 4 in Santner et al. (2003).

Let the basis functions be φ1,…,φqsubscript𝜑1…subscript𝜑𝑞\varphi_{1},\ldots,\varphi_{q} for q≤n𝑞𝑛q\leq n and define the matrix V​(X)∈ℝn×q𝑉𝑋superscriptℝ𝑛𝑞{V(X)\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times q}} with elements

(V​(X))i,j=φj​(xi).subscript𝑉𝑋𝑖𝑗subscript𝜑𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖(V(X))_{i,j}=\varphi_{j}(x_{i}).

Suppose that the mean function is m=∑j=1qβj​φj𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑞subscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝜑𝑗m=\sum_{j=1}^{q}\beta_{j}\varphi_{j} for unknown coefficients β=(β1,…,βq)𝛽subscript𝛽1…subscript𝛽𝑞\beta=(\beta_{1},\ldots,\beta_{q}) which we wish to estimate using maximum likelihood. The full modified log-likelihood function for both the kernel parameters θ𝜃\theta and the coefficients β𝛽\beta is obtained by inserting the parametric prior mean in (2.8):

ℓ​(θ,β∣Y)=(Y−V​(X)​β)𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​(Y−V​(X)​β)+log​detKθ​(X,X).ℓ𝜃conditional𝛽𝑌superscript𝑌𝑉𝑋𝛽𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑌𝑉𝑋𝛽subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋\ell(\theta,\beta\mid Y)=(Y-V(X)\beta)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}(Y-V(X)\beta)+\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X). (3.3)

Any maximum likelihood estimates satisfy

{θML,βML}∈arg​minθ∈Θ,β∈ℝq⁡ℓ​(θ,β∣Y).subscript𝜃MLsubscript𝛽MLsubscriptargminformulae-sequence𝜃Θ𝛽superscriptℝ𝑞ℓ𝜃conditional𝛽𝑌\{\theta_{\textup{ML}},\beta_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta,\,\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{q}}\ell(\theta,\beta\mid Y).

The natural generalisation of Definition 2.1 to this setting is that there exist some coefficients for which the data are m𝑚m-constant. That is, that there exist constants c𝑐c and β∗=(β1∗,…,βq∗)superscript𝛽superscriptsubscript𝛽1…superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑞\beta^{*}=(\beta_{1}^{*},\ldots,\beta_{q}^{*}) (which need not be unique) such that

yi−∑j=1qβj∗​φj​(xi)=c for every i=1,…,n.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑗subscript𝜑𝑗subscript𝑥𝑖𝑐 for every 𝑖1…𝑛y_{i}-\sum_{j=1}^{q}\beta_{j}^{*}\varphi_{j}(x_{i})=c\quad\text{ for every }\quad i=1,\ldots,n. (3.4)

The next theorem shows that the maximum likelihood estimate of the lengthscale parameter λ𝜆\lambda is badly behaved if the data satisfy the above assumption.

Theorem 3.3

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. If the data Y𝑌Y satisfy (3.4), then

λML=∞ if {λML,βML}∈arg​minλ>0,β∈ℝq⁡ℓ​(λ,β∣Y).formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆ML if subscript𝜆MLsubscript𝛽MLsubscriptargminformulae-sequence𝜆0𝛽superscriptℝ𝑞ℓ𝜆conditional𝛽𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty\quad\text{ if }\quad\{\lambda_{\textup{ML}},\beta_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0,\,\beta\in\mathbb{R}^{q}}\ell(\lambda,\beta\mid Y).

Proof  See Section 7.6. The proof is similar to that of Equation 2.11 in Theorem 2.3.  

Remark 3.4

If the matrix V​(X)𝑉𝑋V(X) has full rank, one can compute that

βML=[V​(X)𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​V​(X)]−1​V​(X)𝖳​Kθ​(X,X)−1​Ysubscript𝛽MLsuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑉𝑋1𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳subscript𝐾𝜃superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑌\beta_{\textup{ML}}=\big{[}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}V(X)\big{]}^{-1}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\theta}(X,X)^{-1}Y

for any fixed θ𝜃\theta. If q=n𝑞𝑛q=n, the matrix V​(X)𝑉𝑋V(X) is square and non-singular so that the above maximum likelihood estimate simplifies to βML=V​(X)−1​Ysubscript𝛽ML𝑉superscript𝑋1𝑌\beta_{\textup{ML}}=V(X)^{-1}Y. Inserting this to (3.3) eliminates the data-fit term and we are left with ℓ​(θ,βML∣Y)=log​detKθ​(X,X)ℓ𝜃conditionalsubscript𝛽ML𝑌subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋\ell(\theta,\beta_{\textup{ML}}\mid Y)=\log\det K_{\theta}(X,X). The maximum likelihood estimate of θ𝜃\theta is therefore obtained by minimising complexity of the model. If θ=λ𝜃𝜆\theta=\lambda, this naturally leads to λML=∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty since this is the only value of the lengthscale parameter for which the covariance matrix becomes singular. The interpretation of this phenomenon is that maximum likelihood estimation picks the simplest possible model if the data are fully explained by the prior mean.

3.3 Simultaneous Estimation of the Scaling Parameter

One typically estimates the lengthscale parameter simultaneously with the scale or magnitude parameter σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0. Suppose that θ={λ,σ}𝜃𝜆𝜎\theta=\{\lambda,\sigma\} and the covariance kernel is parametrised as Kθ​(x,y)=σ2​Kλ​(x,y)subscript𝐾𝜃𝑥𝑦superscript𝜎2subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦K_{\theta}(x,y)=\sigma^{2}K_{\lambda}(x,y). Then

ℓ​(λ,σ∣Y)=1σ2​Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym+log​detKλ​(X,X)+n​log⁡σ2ℓ𝜆conditional𝜎𝑌1superscript𝜎2superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋𝑛superscript𝜎2\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log\sigma^{2}

and maximum likelihood estimates satisfy

{λML,σML}∈arg​minσ,λ>0⁡ℓ​(λ,σ∣Y).subscript𝜆MLsubscript𝜎MLsubscriptargmin𝜎𝜆0ℓ𝜆conditional𝜎𝑌\{\lambda_{\textup{ML}},\sigma_{\textup{ML}}\}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\sigma,\lambda>0}\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y). (3.5)

Unfortunately, the behaviour of the maximum likelihood estimate λMLsubscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}} is identical to the case in Theorem 2.3 where σ𝜎\sigma is held fixed. Let σML​(λ)subscript𝜎ML𝜆\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda) denote the maximum likelihood estimate of σ𝜎\sigma for a fixed λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0.

Theorem 3.5 (Simultaneous estimation)

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. Consider the maximum likelihood estimates in (3.5). If the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant and Ym≠0subscript𝑌𝑚0Y_{m}\neq 0, then

limλ→∞ℓ​(λ,σML​(λ)∣Y)=−∞ and λML=∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆ℓ𝜆conditionalsubscript𝜎ML𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda,\sigma_{\textup{ML}}(\lambda)\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty.

Proof  See Section 7.6. The proof does not fundamentally differ from that of Theorem 2.3.  

If it happens that Ym=0subscript𝑌𝑚0Y_{m}=0, the modified log-likelihood function is simply

ℓ​(λ,σ∣Y)=log​detKλ​(X,X)+n​log⁡σ2.ℓ𝜆conditional𝜎𝑌subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋𝑛superscript𝜎2\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)+n\log\sigma^{2}.

Then ℓ​(λ,σ∣Y)=−∞ℓ𝜆conditional𝜎𝑌\ell(\lambda,\sigma\mid Y)=-\infty if and only if λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty or σ→0→𝜎0\sigma\to 0. Either of these cases results zero conditional variance and degenerate predictive distributions.

4 Regularisation

This section discusses two types of regularisation that can be used to ensure the well-posedness of Gaussian process regression or finiteness of a lengthscale estimator. However, these approaches may induce unwanted side effects and are, to some extent, arbitrary.

4.1 Regularisation via Observation Noise

Let δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 be a regularisation parameter (alternatively, smoothing parameter, nugget or jitter). Denote the n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n identity matrix with Insubscript𝐼𝑛I_{n}. The regularised versions of the Gaussian process conditional mean and covariance in (2.4) and (2.5) are

μδ​(x)superscript𝜇𝛿𝑥\displaystyle\mu^{\delta}(x) =m​(x)+K​(x,X)𝖳​(K​(X,X)+δ2​In)−1​Ym,absent𝑚𝑥𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳superscript𝐾𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛1subscript𝑌𝑚\displaystyle=m(x)+K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}Y_{m},
Pδ​(x,y)2superscript𝑃𝛿superscript𝑥𝑦2\displaystyle P^{\delta}(x,y)^{2} =K​(x,y)−K​(x,X)𝖳​(K​(X,X)+δ2​In)−1​K​(X,y)absent𝐾𝑥𝑦𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳superscript𝐾𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛1𝐾𝑋𝑦\displaystyle=K(x,y)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}K(X,y)

and that of the modified log-likelihood function is

ℓδ​(λ∣Y)=Ym𝖳​(Kλ​(X,X)+δ2​In)−1​Ym+log​det(Kλ​(X,X)+δ2​In).superscriptℓ𝛿conditional𝜆𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛\ell^{\delta}(\lambda\mid Y)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}Y_{m}+\log\det(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n}). (4.1)

In this section every quantity which is superscripted with δ𝛿\delta stands for the corresponding quantity defined in Section 2 but with K​(X,X)𝐾𝑋𝑋K(X,X) replaced by K​(X,X)+δ2​In𝐾𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n}. Although the above expressions arise from assuming that the data are corrupted by additive and independent zero-mean Gaussian noise terms with variances δ2superscript𝛿2\delta^{2}, regularisation is often used purely out of convenience (that is, even when one does not believe that the data are noisy) as it improves the condition number of the covariance matrix that needs to be inverted (e.g., Ranjan et al., 2011; Adrianakis and Challenor, 2012).

Because (K​(X,X)+δ2​In)−1<K​(X,X)−1superscript𝐾𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛1𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1(K(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}<K(X,X)^{-1} in the Loewner ordering of positive-semidefinite matrices, we easily derive that the regularised conditional variance is everywhere positive:

Pδ​(x)2=Pδ​(x,x)2>P​(x)2≥0 for every x∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑃𝛿superscript𝑥2superscript𝑃𝛿superscript𝑥𝑥2𝑃superscript𝑥20 for every 𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑P^{\delta}(x)^{2}=P^{\delta}(x,x)^{2}>P(x)^{2}\geq 0\quad\text{ for every }\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Consider then the lengthscale parameter λ𝜆\lambda and the corresponding kernel Kλsubscript𝐾𝜆K_{\lambda} and assume for simplicity that Kλ​(x,y)→1→subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦1K_{\lambda}(x,y)\to 1 as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty for all x,y∈Ω𝑥𝑦Ωx,y\in\Omega. Then it is straightforward to use the Sherman–Morrison formula to compute that

limλ→∞Pλδ​(x)2=limλ→∞[Kλ​(x,y)−Kλ​(x,X)𝖳​(Kλ​(X,X)+δ2​In)−1​Kλ​(x,X)]=11+n​δ−2subscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑃𝜆𝛿superscript𝑥2subscript→𝜆delimited-[]subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳superscriptsubscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋superscript𝛿2subscript𝐼𝑛1subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑋11𝑛superscript𝛿2\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}^{\delta}(x)^{2}=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\big{[}K_{\lambda}(x,y)-K_{\lambda}(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}(K_{\lambda}(X,X)+\delta^{2}I_{n})^{-1}K_{\lambda}(x,X)\big{]}=\frac{1}{1+n\delta^{-2}}

and

limλ→∞μλδ​(x)=m​(x)+δ−21+n​δ−2​∑i=1n(yi−m​(xi))subscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝜇𝜆𝛿𝑥𝑚𝑥superscript𝛿21𝑛superscript𝛿2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑦𝑖𝑚subscript𝑥𝑖\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}^{\delta}(x)=m(x)+\frac{\delta^{-2}}{1+n\delta^{-2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_{i}-m(x_{i}))

for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and Ym∈ℝnsubscript𝑌𝑚superscriptℝ𝑛Y_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. These estimates and computations establish that under regularisation no finite-dimensional distribution of the conditional Gaussian process can tend to a degenerate Gaussian as λ𝜆\lambda varies. It follows that regularised Gaussian process interpolation is well-posed in the sense discussed in Section 2.4 as long as the estimator of λ𝜆\lambda is continuous in the data. However, the price one pays for vanquishing ill-conditioning is that the conditional mean no longer interpolates the data, which may be undesirable in applications where the data are truly noiseless, and that an additional degree of freedom is introduced. Favorable convergence rates of Gaussian process interpolation (asymptotically as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty) are also lost under regularisation unless one has the regularisation parameter tend to zero with an appropriate rate (Wendland and Rieger, 2005, Section 3).

Even though maximum likelihood estimation of λ𝜆\lambda cannot cause ill-posedness in the regularised setting (assuming the estimator is continuous in the data), there remains the interesting question of how λMLδsuperscriptsubscript𝜆ML𝛿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta}, as computed by minimising the regularised modified log-likelihood function in (4.1), behaves if the data are m𝑚m-constant. Our attempts at proving any properties of λMLδsuperscriptsubscript𝜆ML𝛿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta} have been unsuccessful, and therefore here we limit ourselves to a simple numerical investigation, the results of which are depicted in Figure 4. This figure plots

λMLδ=arg​minλ>0⁡ℓδ​(λ∣Y)superscriptsubscript𝜆ML𝛿subscriptargmin𝜆0superscriptℓ𝛿conditional𝜆𝑌\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\lambda>0}\ell^{\delta}(\lambda\mid Y) (4.2)

as a function of δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 for four different data vectors Y∈ℝ3𝑌superscriptℝ3Y\in\mathbb{R}^{3} (we set m≡0𝑚0m\equiv 0) when X={1,1.2,2.0}⊂ℝ𝑋11.22.0ℝX=\{1,1.2,2.0\}\subset\mathbb{R} and K𝐾K is the Matérn kernel in (2.3) with parameters σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1 and ν=3/2𝜈32\nu=3/2. Minimisation was performed using grid search. It appears that for each data set the maximum likelihood estimate λMLδsuperscriptsubscript𝜆ML𝛿\lambda_{\textup{ML}}^{\delta} has a singularity at a certain value δ∞subscript𝛿\delta_{\infty} of δ𝛿\delta and that δ∞subscript𝛿\delta_{\infty} is smaller when the data Y𝑌Y are closer to being constant. This suggests that, for a sufficiently large δ𝛿\delta, maximum likelihood estimation always reverts to the simplest possible model, that obtained with λ=∞𝜆\lambda=\infty. One way to interpret this observation is that any given data set could have been plausibly generated by a constant function if the data set is assumed to be corrupted by Gaussian noise with sufficiently large variance (i.e., if δ2superscript𝛿2\delta^{2} is sufficiently large).

4.2 Regularisation via Lengthscale Hyperprior

Suppose that a prior with a density function p𝑝p is placed on the parameters θ𝜃\theta. Then the posterior for θ𝜃\theta has the log-density

log⁡p​(θ∣Y)=−12​ℓ​(θ∣Y)+log⁡p​(θ)+constant,𝑝conditional𝜃𝑌12ℓconditional𝜃𝑌𝑝𝜃constant\log p(\theta\mid Y)=-\frac{1}{2}\ell(\theta\mid Y)+\log p(\theta)+\text{constant},

where ℓ​(θ∣Y)ℓconditional𝜃𝑌\ell(\theta\mid Y) is the modified log-likelihood function in (2.8). Any maximiser θMAPsubscript𝜃MAP\theta_{\textup{MAP}} of the posterior density is called a maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate of θ𝜃\theta. Equivalently,

θMAP∈arg​minθ∈Θ⁡ℓMAP​(θ∣Y) for ℓMAP​(θ∣Y)=12​ℓ​(θ∣Y)−log⁡p​(θ).formulae-sequencesubscript𝜃MAPsubscriptargmin𝜃ΘsubscriptℓMAPconditional𝜃𝑌 for subscriptℓMAPconditional𝜃𝑌12ℓconditional𝜃𝑌𝑝𝜃\theta_{\textup{MAP}}\in\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\theta\in\Theta}\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\theta\mid Y)\quad\text{ for }\quad\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\theta\mid Y)=\frac{1}{2}\ell(\theta\mid Y)-\log p(\theta). (4.3)

The following theorem shows that assigning a non-heavy-tailed hyperprior on the lengthscale λ𝜆\lambda ensures that its MAP estimate is finite regardless of the data.

Theorem 4.1

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2, n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, and

λ(α−d/2)​n​p​(λ)→0 as λ→∞,formulae-sequence→superscript𝜆𝛼𝑑2𝑛𝑝𝜆0 as →𝜆\lambda^{(\alpha-d/2)n}p(\lambda)\to 0\quad\text{ as }\quad\lambda\to\infty, (4.4)

where α>d/2𝛼𝑑2\alpha>d/2 is the constant in Assumption 2.2. If Y∈ℝn𝑌superscriptℝ𝑛Y\in\mathbb{R}^{n} are any data, then

limλ→∞ℓMAP​(λ∣Y)=∞ and λMAP<∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆subscriptℓMAPconditional𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆MAP\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{MAP}}<\infty.

Proof  See Section 7.7. The essence of the proof is that the assumption on tail decay of p𝑝p ensures that −log⁡p​(λ)𝑝𝜆-\log p(\lambda) dominates ℓMAP​(λ∣Y)subscriptℓMAPconditional𝜆𝑌\ell_{\textup{MAP}}(\lambda\mid Y) as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty.  

Because, for fixed Y𝑌Y, the choice of the hyperprior p𝑝p completely determines the estimator, MAP estimation is rather arbitrary and not well-suited to deployment in general-purpose software.

5 Generalisations and Extensions

This section discusses some generalisations of Theorem 2.3 for (a) general linear data, (b) lengthscale estimation for product kernels, and (c) kernels which do not satisfy the Fourier decay assumption in (2.9).

5.1 Linear Information and General Kernels

In this section we generalise part of Theorem 2.3 by replacing the domain ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with an arbitrary vector space ΩΩ\Omega, using a more liberal definition of a lengthscale parameter, and considering general linear data, such as derivative evaluations. Though somewhat technical, the assumptions that this generalisation requires can be verified in some settings of practical interest.

Let ΩΩ\Omega be a vector space and Kθ:Ω×Ω→ℝ:subscript𝐾𝜃→ΩΩℝK_{\theta}\colon\Omega\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R} a positive-definite kernel on ΩΩ\Omega for each θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta. We use H​(Kθ,Ω)𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃ΩH(K_{\theta},\Omega) to denote the RKHS of Kθsubscript𝐾𝜃K_{\theta} on ΩΩ\Omega; see Section 7.1 for details. Let F​(Ω)𝐹ΩF(\Omega) be a set of real-valued functions defined on ΩΩ\Omega which contains H​(Kθ,Ω)𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃ΩH(K_{\theta},\Omega) for every θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta as well as all constant functions and the prior mean function m𝑚m. Let ℒ={L1,…,Ln}ℒsubscript𝐿1…subscript𝐿𝑛\mathcal{L}=\{L_{1},\ldots,L_{n}\} be a collection of n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2 non-trivial (i.e., none of them is the zero functional) linear information functionals defined on F​(Ω)𝐹ΩF(\Omega). These functionals are assumed to be linearly independent and bounded on H​(Kθ,Ω)𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃ΩH(K_{\theta},\Omega) for every θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta, in that there is Cθ>0subscript𝐶𝜃0C_{\theta}>0 such that |Li​(f)|≤Cθ​∥f∥H​(Kθ,Ω)subscript𝐿𝑖𝑓subscript𝐶𝜃subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃Ω\mathinner{\lvert L_{i}(f)\rvert}\leq C_{\theta}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K_{\theta},\Omega)} for every f∈H​(Kθ,Ω)𝑓𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃Ωf\in H(K_{\theta},\Omega). We assume that the data

Yℒ=(L1​f,…,Ln​f)∈ℝnsubscript𝑌ℒsubscript𝐿1𝑓…subscript𝐿𝑛𝑓superscriptℝ𝑛Y_{\mathcal{L}}=(L_{1}f,\ldots,L_{n}f)\in\mathbb{R}^{n} (5.1)

consist of applications of the information functionals to an underlying (and unknown) data-generating function f∈F​(Ω)𝑓𝐹Ωf\in F(\Omega). The setting considered earlier in this article is recovered by selecting the point evaluation functionals defined as Li​f=f​(xi)subscript𝐿𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖L_{i}f=f(x_{i}). Partial derivative data, defined by Li​f=∂pif​(xi)subscript𝐿𝑖𝑓subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖L_{i}f=\partial_{p_{i}}f(x_{i}) for some xi∈Ωsubscript𝑥𝑖Ωx_{i}\in\Omega and pi≥0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}\geq 0, also occurs commonly in Gaussian process applications (e.g., Solak et al., 2002). Let ℒ​(m)=(Li​m)i=1n∈ℝnℒ𝑚superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑚𝑖1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{L}(m)=(L_{i}m)_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and set Yℒ,m=Yℒ−ℒ​(m)∈ℝnsubscript𝑌ℒ𝑚subscript𝑌ℒℒ𝑚superscriptℝ𝑛Y_{\mathcal{L},m}=Y_{\mathcal{L}}-\mathcal{L}(m)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. Also set

Kθ​(ℒ,ℒ)=(Lix​Ljy​Kθ​(x,y))i,j=1n∈ℝn×n and Kθ​(ℒ,x)=(Li​Kθ​(⋅,x))i=1n∈ℝn,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐾𝜃ℒℒsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑥superscriptsubscript𝐿𝑗𝑦subscript𝐾𝜃𝑥𝑦𝑖𝑗1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛 and subscript𝐾𝜃ℒ𝑥superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐿𝑖subscript𝐾𝜃⋅𝑥𝑖1𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},\mathcal{L})=(L_{i}^{x}L_{j}^{y}K_{\theta}(x,y))_{i,j=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}\quad\text{ and }\quad K_{\theta}(\mathcal{L},x)=(L_{i}K_{\theta}(\cdot,x))_{i=1}^{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n},

which are well-defined by the assumption that the information functionals are bounded on H​(Kθ,Ω)𝐻subscript𝐾𝜃ΩH(K_{\theta},\Omega). Let g:(0,∞)→(0,∞):𝑔→00g\colon(0,\infty)\to(0,\infty) be a continuous function such that (a) lim supλ→0g​(λ)<∞subscriptlimit-supremum→𝜆0𝑔𝜆\limsup_{\lambda\to 0}g(\lambda)<\infty, (b) limλ→∞g​(λ)=∞subscript→𝜆𝑔𝜆\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}g(\lambda)=\infty, and (c) g​(λ1)=1𝑔subscript𝜆11g(\lambda_{1})=1 for some λ1>0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}>0. The parameter λ𝜆\lambda can be interpreted as a generalised version of the lengthscale parameter of a stationary kernel in (1.2). Stationary kernels are recovered from (5.3) by setting g​(λ)=λ𝑔𝜆𝜆g(\lambda)=\lambda and K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y). The exponential kernel Kλ​(x,y)=exp⁡(x​y/λ)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦𝜆K_{\lambda}(x,y)=\exp(xy/\lambda) is a simple non-stationary example that is occasionally used. 5.2 Product Kernels and Multiple Lengthscales

Here we consider a setting where the covariance kernel is a product of stationary kernels equipped with dimensionwise lengthscale parameters. That is, θ={λ1,…,λd}𝜃subscript𝜆1…subscript𝜆𝑑\theta=\{\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\} and the kernel has the product form
