in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} and the prior mean m≡0𝑚0m\equiv 0.

Theorem 5.3 (Estimation of multiple lengthscales)

Consider the product kernel in (5.6) and suppose that the stationary kernels K1,…,Kdsubscript𝐾1…subscript𝐾𝑑K_{1},\ldots,K_{d} on ℝℝ\mathbb{R} satisfy Assumption 2.2. If X𝑋X has the product form (5.8) with ni≥1subscript𝑛𝑖1n_{i}\geq 1 for each i=1,…,d𝑖1…𝑑i=1,\ldots,d and the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant along dimension p∈{1,…,d}𝑝1…𝑑p\in\{1,\ldots,d\}, then

limλp→∞ℓ​(λ1,…,λd∣Y)=−∞ and λp,ML=∞,formulae-sequencesubscript→subscript𝜆𝑝ℓsubscript𝜆1…conditionalsubscript𝜆𝑑𝑌 and subscript𝜆𝑝ML\lim_{\lambda_{p}\to\infty}\ell(\lambda_{1},\ldots,\lambda_{d}\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{p,\textup{ML}}=\infty,

where λp,MLsubscript𝜆𝑝ML\lambda_{p,\textup{ML}} is the maximum likelihood estimate of the p𝑝pth lengthscale parameter in (5.7).

Proof  See Section 7.9. The product form of the kernel and the covariates allow one to write the full covariance matrix Kθ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜃𝑋𝑋K_{\theta}(X,X) as a Kronecker product of Ki,λ​(Xi,Xi)subscript𝐾𝑖𝜆subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖K_{i,\lambda}(X_{i},X_{i}). One may then utilise the properties of Kronecker products and subsequently follow the proof of Theorem 2.3.  

Note that the constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} and α𝛼\alpha in Assumption 2.2 may differ from one constituent kernel Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i} to another. Theorem 5.3 provides some theoretical justification for the use of maximum likelihood estimation of lengthscales as an automatic relevance determination method (Rasmussen and Williams, 2006, Section 5.1). When the data are independent of the p𝑝pth input dimension, the lengthscale for this dimension is set to infinite and the dimension is effectively ignored.

5.3 Infinitely Smooth Stationary Kernels

Commonly used infinitely smooth stationary kernels, such as the Gaussian and the inverse quadratic (or Cauchy) defined by

Φ​(z)=exp⁡(−∥z∥2) and Φ​(z)=11+∥z∥2,formulae-sequenceΦ𝑧superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑧2 and Φ𝑧11superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑧2\Phi(z)=\exp(-\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}^{2})\quad\text{ and }\quad\Phi(z)=\frac{1}{1+\mathinner{\lVert z\rVert}^{2}}, (5.9)

respectively, do not satisfy Assumption 2.2 because their Fourier transforms decay (at least) exponentially. The exponential decay of their Fourier transforms implies that these kernels are analytic. The purpose of Assumption 2.2 is to guarantee that constant functions are contained in the RKHS of K𝐾K on a bounded set, a result which in turn can be exploited to prove that the data-fit term Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ymsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} is a bounded function of λ𝜆\lambda whenever the data are m𝑚m-constant (see Lemma 7.2). However, it is known that the RKHSs of analytic stationary kernels, such as those in (5.9), do not contain constant functions (Steinwart et al., 2006; Sun and Zhou, 2008; Minh, 2010; Dette and Zhigljavsky, 2021). But this does have to mean that the data-fit term explodes as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty.

Increasing the lengthscale parameter is equivalent to coalescence of the points to the origin. That is, using the kernel Kλsubscript𝐾𝜆K_{\lambda} and points X𝑋X is equivalent to using the kernel K𝐾K and the scaled points Xλ={x1/λ,…,xn/λ}subscript𝑋𝜆subscript𝑥1𝜆…subscript𝑥𝑛𝜆X_{\lambda}=\{x_{1}/\lambda,\ldots,x_{n}/\lambda\}, each of which tends to the origin as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. Suppose for simplicity that d=1𝑑1d=1. When the points coalesce, one’s data effectively comprises the value at the origin of the data-generating function and its successive derivatives up to order n−1𝑛1n-1. We refer to Section 11 in Schaback (2008) and Chapter 5 in Oettershagen (2017) for more discussion and some results regarding this phenomenon. The computations in Section 2 of Dette and Zhigljavsky (2021) are also relevant. If the data are m𝑚m-constant such that Ym=(c,…,c)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑐…𝑐Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) and the kernel K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) is sufficiently smooth, this reasoning suggests the conjecture that

limλ→∞Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym=limλ→∞Ym𝖳​K​(Xλ,Xλ)−1​Ym=D0𝖳​W−1​D0subscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚subscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑋𝜆subscript𝑋𝜆1subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐷0𝖳superscript𝑊1subscript𝐷0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda})^{-1}Y_{m}=D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0} (5.10)

where D0=(c,0,…,0)∈ℝnsubscript𝐷0𝑐0…0superscriptℝ𝑛D_{0}=(c,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{n} and the Wronskian W∈ℝn×n𝑊superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛W\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n} has the elements

(W)i+1,j+1=∂i+j∂vi​∂wjK(v,w)|v=0w=0(W)_{i+1,j+1}=\frac{\partial^{i+j}}{\partial v^{i}\partial w^{j}}K(v,w)\Bigl{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}v=0\\ w=0\end{subarray}} (5.11)

for i,j=0,…,n−1formulae-sequence𝑖𝑗0…𝑛1i,j=0,\ldots,n-1. The conjectured limit D0𝖳​W−1​D0superscriptsubscript𝐷0𝖳superscript𝑊1subscript𝐷0D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0} is the data-fit term in (5.2) for the information functionals defined as Li​f=f(i−1)​(0)subscript𝐿𝑖𝑓superscript𝑓𝑖10L_{i}f=f^{(i-1)}(0) for i=1,…,n𝑖1…𝑛i=1,\ldots,n and general m𝑚m-constant data in (5.4). A proof of (5.10) is the main ingredient in the proof of the following theorem, which partially generalises Theorem 2.3 for infinitely differentiable kernels when d=1𝑑1d=1.

Theorem 5.4

Let d=1𝑑1d=1 and K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y). Suppose that (i) the function Φ:ℝ→ℝ:Φ→ℝℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} is integrable and infinitely differentiable in a neighbourhood of the origin; (ii) Φ(k)​(0)=0superscriptΦ𝑘00\Phi^{(k)}(0)=0 for every odd k𝑘k; and (iii) the Fourier transform of ΦΦ\Phi is everywhere positive. If n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 and the data Y𝑌Y are m𝑚m-constant, then

limλ→∞ℓ​(λ∣Y)=−∞ and λML=∞.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆ℓconditional𝜆𝑌 and subscript𝜆ML\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell(\lambda\mid Y)=-\infty\quad\text{ and }\quad\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty.

Proof  See Section 7.10. The proof uses Equation (32) in Barthelmé and Usevich (2021).  

6 Conclusion and Implications

In this article we have proved that Gaussian process regression with noiseless data and a stationary covariance kernel is ill-posed if the lengthscale parameter of the kernel is estimated using maximum likelihood: When the data differ from the prior mean by a constant mean shift, the maximum likelihood estimate of the lengthscale parameter is infinite (Theorem 2.3) and the conditional Gaussian process is degenerate (Theorem 2.6). As shown in Section 3, these conclusions remain valid under more general parametrisations and also applies to leave-one-out cross-validation.

6.1 Practical Implications

In a way, our results imply a practical simplification. If the data are m𝑚m-constant (which, when the prior mean m𝑚m is known and fixed, is trivial to check), there is no need for numerical optimisation of the log-likelihood function as one can use Theorem 2.3 to set λML=∞subscript𝜆ML\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\infty and Theorem 2.6 to compute the conditional mean and covariance. However, degeneracy of the resulting conditional process implies that there is no predictive uncertainty and the conditional process is therefore useless as a tool for uncertainty quantification. Except for switching to a non-stationary kernel, we do not know of a good approach to fix this, and it may be that some non-stationary kernels are equally problematic and induce similar behaviour when some of their parameters are estimated.

A numerical issue that is encountered when the data are close to being m𝑚m-constant is that of ill-conditioning of the covariance matrix. As λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty, the condition number of the covariance matrix Kλ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋K_{\lambda}(X,X) increases with a rate related to the smoothness of the kernel. This means that one cannot compute the modified log-likelihood function for large values of λ𝜆\lambda. In practice one therefore has to either introduce a regularisation parameter to upper bound the condition number as a function of λ𝜆\lambda or select a finite maximal lengthscale λmax>0subscript𝜆max0\lambda_{\textup{max}}>0 for which ℓ​(λ∣Y)ℓconditional𝜆𝑌\ell(\lambda\mid Y) can be reliably computed and find the maximum likelihood estimate in (0,λmax]0subscript𝜆max(0,\lambda_{\textup{max}}]. When the data are m𝑚m-constant, restricting the feasible set for λ𝜆\lambda to (0,λmax]0subscript𝜆max(0,\lambda_{\textup{max}}] is likely to result in λML=λmaxsubscript𝜆MLsubscript𝜆max\lambda_{\textup{ML}}=\lambda_{\textup{max}}, so that the user effectively selects an arbitrary (though probably fairly large) lengthscale in this case. The dependence of predictions in λmaxsubscript𝜆max\lambda_{\textup{max}} may or may not be problematic depending on the context.

A practical recommendation borne out by our results is that all Gaussian process implementations which use maximum likelihood but not regularisation should check if the data are m𝑚m-constant. If the check indicates that the data are m𝑚m-constant, an implementation should either (a) forgo lengthscale estimation and output a degenerate conditional process or (b) throw an error and inform the user of the problem. If the approach (a) is chosen it should be made clear to the user that the output is degenerate as this may have important ramifications in the applied context. A more general research programme suggests itself:

  1. (i)

    To characterise, for each estimator of the kernel parameters θ𝜃\theta, the problematic data sets Y𝑌Y which cause Gaussian process regression or interpolation to be ill-posed.

  2. (ii)

    To hard-code Gaussian process software to throw an error (or at least a warning) when such data are encountered.

6.2 Theoretical Implications

When analysing the convergence of Gaussian process regression as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty, it is typically assumed that the covariance kernel is fixed. To the best of our knowledge, in the deterministic interpolation regime only Teckentrup (2020) and Wynne et al. (2021) allow the kernel parameters other than scaling parameter σ𝜎\sigma from Section 3.3 (which does not affect the conditional mean) to vary. Their results are generic in that no specific parameter estimation method is considered and the parameter estimates are simply assumed to remain within certain sets. In Wynne et al. (2021) only a smoothness parameter, such as the parameter ν𝜈\nu of Matérn kernels (2.3), is allowed to vary. Teckentrup (2020, Theorem 3.5) considers kernels which satisfy Assumption 2.2 and proves that the conditional mean in (2.4) tends to the true data-generating function f𝑓f such that Y=f​(X)𝑌𝑓𝑋Y=f(X) if (i) this function has certain smoothness and (ii) there is a compact set which contains the estimate of λ𝜆\lambda for every n𝑛n. As we have seen in this article, the second assumption fails if f𝑓f happens to be a mean shift of the prior mean (i.e., f=m+c𝑓𝑚𝑐f=m+c for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R}) and λ𝜆\lambda is estimated using maximum likelihood. This demonstrates that unless one imposes an artificial upper bound on the parameter estimates, smoothness assumptions alone are not sufficient for comprehensive convergence analysis of Gaussian process regression.

6.3 On Estimation of Other Parameters

We conclude by pointing out that our ill-posedness results are specific to lengthscale estimation and should not be expected to extend to estimation of other kernel parameters. Two examples serve to illustrate this. First, consider the scale parametrisation Kσ​(x,y)=σ2​K​(x,y)subscript𝐾𝜎𝑥𝑦superscript𝜎2𝐾𝑥𝑦K_{\sigma}(x,y)=\sigma^{2}K(x,y) for a scale parameter σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0. From (2.8) it is straightforward to compute that the maximum likelihood estimate of σ𝜎\sigma is available in closed form:

σML=Ym𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​Ymn.subscript𝜎MLsuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚𝑛\sigma_{\textup{ML}}=\sqrt{\frac{Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}}{n}}.

Here only the data Y=m​(X)𝑌𝑚𝑋Y=m(X) yield a problematic parameter estimate σML=0subscript𝜎ML0\sigma_{\textup{ML}}=0 that results in degenerate predictive distributions. Consider then estimation of the smoothness parameter ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 of a Matérn kernel Kνsubscript𝐾𝜈K_{\nu} in (2.3). The presence of the coefficient 21−ν/Γ​(ν)superscript21𝜈Γ𝜈2^{1-\nu}/\Gamma(\nu) ensures that Kν​(x,x)=σ2subscript𝐾𝜈𝑥𝑥superscript𝜎2K_{\nu}(x,x)=\sigma^{2} for every ν>0𝜈0\nu>0, which has two implications:

  • •

    As is well known, Kν​(x,y)subscript𝐾𝜈𝑥𝑦K_{\nu}(x,y) tends to the Gaussian kernel σ2​exp⁡(−∥x−y∥2/(2​λ2))superscript𝜎2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑦22superscript𝜆2\sigma^{2}\exp(-\mathinner{\lVert x-y\rVert}^{2}\!/(2\lambda^{2})) as ν→∞→𝜈\nu\to\infty for all x,y∈ℝd𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑑x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

  • •

    As ν→0→𝜈0\nu\to 0, Kν​(x,y)→σ2→subscript𝐾𝜈𝑥𝑦superscript𝜎2K_{\nu}(x,y)\to\sigma^{2} if x=y𝑥𝑦x=y and Kν​(x,y)→0→subscript𝐾𝜈𝑥𝑦0K_{\nu}(x,y)\to 0 if x≠y𝑥𝑦x\neq y. The latter of these claims follows from the facts that 𝒦0​(z)subscript𝒦0𝑧\mathcal{K}_{0}(z), the Bessel function of the second kind of zeroth order, is well-defined if z≠0𝑧0z\neq 0 and Γ​(ν)→∞→Γ𝜈\Gamma(\nu)\to\infty as ν→0→𝜈0\nu\to 0.

This shows that both potentially problematic limiting cases, ν→0→𝜈0\nu\to 0 and ν→∞→𝜈\nu\to\infty, yield valid positive-definite kernels. Consequently, degenerate predictive distributions can never arise from estimation of the Matérn smoothness parameter.

7 Proofs

This section contains proofs for the results in Sections 2, 3, 4 and 5.

7.1 Interpolation in Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces

Let ΩΩ\Omega be an arbitrary set and K:Ω×Ω→ℝ:𝐾→ΩΩℝK\colon\Omega\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R} a positive-definite kernel, which means that

∑n=1n∑j=1nai​aj​K​(xi,xj)>0superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗𝐾subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗0\sum_{n=1}^{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{i}a_{j}K(x_{i},x_{j})>0 (7.1)

for any n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}, any non-zero vector a=(a1,…,an)𝑎subscript𝑎1…subscript𝑎𝑛a=(a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}), and any distinct points xi∈Ωsubscript𝑥𝑖Ωx_{i}\in\Omega. The kernel is positive-semidefinite if the inequality in (7.1) is not required to be strict. Then K𝐾K induces a unique reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS), H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega). This is a Hilbert space consisting of real-valued functions defined on ΩΩ\Omega and is equipped with an inner product ⟨⋅,⋅⟩H​(K,Ω)subscript⋅⋅𝐻𝐾Ω\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)} and the corresponding norm ∥⋅∥H​(K,Ω)subscriptdelimited-∥∥⋅𝐻𝐾Ω\mathinner{\lVert\cdot\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}. The kernel translate K​(⋅,x)𝐾⋅𝑥K(\cdot,x) is an element of H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega) for every x∈Ω𝑥Ωx\in\Omega and the kernel has the reproducing property

⟨K​(⋅,x),f⟩H​(K,Ω)=f​(x) for all x∈Ω​ and ​f∈H​(K,Ω).formulae-sequencesubscript𝐾⋅𝑥𝑓𝐻𝐾Ω𝑓𝑥 for all 𝑥Ω and 𝑓𝐻𝐾Ω\langle K(\cdot,x),f\rangle_{H(K,\Omega)}=f(x)\quad\text{ for all }\quad x\in\Omega\>\text{ and }\>f\in H(K,\Omega).

It is usually not straightforward to determine whether or not a given function is an element of H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega). However, the RKHS of a kernel which satisfies Assumption 2.2 on the rate of decay of its Fourier transform is a Sobolev space; see Section 7.3. For more information on RKHSs we refer the reader to Berlinet and Thomas-Agnan (2004) and Chapters 10 and 16 in Wendland (2005).

We are interested in optimal interpolation in an RKHS. Let f:Ω→ℝ:𝑓→Ωℝf\colon\Omega\to\mathbb{R} be any function (i.e., not necessarily an element of the RKHS) that is to be interpolated at a set of distinct points X={xi}i=1n⊂Ω𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛ΩX=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}\subset\Omega. The kernel interpolant sf,Xsubscript𝑠𝑓𝑋s_{f,X} is the unique minimum norm interpolant to f𝑓f at these points:

sf,X=arg​mins∈H​(K,Ω)⁡{∥s∥H​(K,Ω):s​(xi)=f​(xi)​ for every ​i=1,…,n}.subscript𝑠𝑓𝑋subscriptargmin𝑠𝐻𝐾Ω:subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑠𝐻𝐾Ω𝑠subscript𝑥𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖 for every 𝑖1…𝑛s_{f,X}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{s\in H(K,\Omega)}\big{\{}\mathinner{\lVert s\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,s(x_{i})=f(x_{i})\text{ for every }i=1,\ldots,n\big{\}}. (7.2)

The kernel interpolant has the explicit linear-algebraic form

sf,X​(x)=K​(x,X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​f​(X),subscript𝑠𝑓𝑋𝑥𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑓𝑋s_{f,X}(x)=K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X), (7.3)

which equals the conditional mean in (2.4) when m≡0𝑚0m\equiv 0. This is the famous equivalence between Gaussian process interpolation and optimal interpolation in an RKHS whose origins can be traced back at least to the work of Kimeldorf and Wahba (1970). From (7.3) it is straightforward to compute that (e.g., Fasshauer, 2011, Section 5.1)

∥sf,X∥H​(K,Ω)2=f​(X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​f​(X),superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑠𝑓𝑋𝐻𝐾Ω2𝑓superscript𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑓𝑋\mathinner{\lVert s_{f,X}\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2}=f(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X), (7.4)

which equals the data-fit term in (2.8) for m≡0𝑚0m\equiv 0. Note that a particular implication of (7.2) and (7.4) is that f​(X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​f​(X)≤∥f∥H​(K,Ω)2𝑓superscript𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1𝑓𝑋superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻𝐾Ω2f(X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}f(X)\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2} if f∈H​(K,Ω)𝑓𝐻𝐾Ωf\in H(K,\Omega). How these properties of sf,Xsubscript𝑠𝑓𝑋s_{f,X} follow is explained in more detail in the proof of Proposition 7.10 concerning interpolation based on general linear data. For the conditional variance we use the notation

PX​(x)2=K​(x,x)−K​(x,X)𝖳​K​(X,X)−1​K​(X,x),subscript𝑃𝑋superscript𝑥2𝐾𝑥𝑥𝐾superscript𝑥𝑋𝖳𝐾superscript𝑋𝑋1𝐾𝑋𝑥P_{X}(x)^{2}=K(x,x)-K(x,X)^{\mathsf{T}}K(X,X)^{-1}K(X,x), (7.5)

which makes the dependency on the points X𝑋X explicit. Now, for every x∈Ω𝑥Ωx\in\Omega it holds that (e.g., Wendland, 2005, Theorem 11.4)

|f​(x)−sf,X​(x)|≤∥f∥H​(K,Ω)​PX​(x)𝑓𝑥subscript𝑠𝑓𝑋𝑥subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻𝐾Ωsubscript𝑃𝑋𝑥\mathinner{\lvert f(x)-s_{f,X}(x)\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}P_{X}(x) (7.6)

if f∈H​(K,Ω)𝑓𝐻𝐾Ωf\in H(K,\Omega), so that the conditional standard deviation controls the interpolation error.

7.2 On Notation

The proofs require notation that is more expressive than what we have used elsewhere in this article. Therefore the conditional variance in (2.5) equals the conditional variance (7.5) whose dependency on the covariates has been made explicit. Similarly, the function s𝑠s in (2.6) equals the kernel interpolant sf,Xsubscript𝑠𝑓𝑋s_{f,X} in (7.3) for any function f𝑓f such that f​(X)=Ym𝑓𝑋subscript𝑌𝑚f(X)=Y_{m}. It is often necessary or useful to indicate that various quantities depend on the kernel parameters (either θ𝜃\theta or λ𝜆\lambda). We use subscripts for this purpose. Subscripts are also used as shorthands for point sets formed by removing some elements of X={xi}i=1n𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} in the following way: Xk={xi}i=1ksubscript𝑋𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑘X_{k}=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} and Xn,k=X∖{xk}subscript𝑋𝑛𝑘𝑋subscript𝑥𝑘X_{n,k}=X\setminus\{x_{k}\}. Analogous notation is used for the conditional standard deviation and mean and the kernel interpolant constructed at these point sets, so that

Pθ,k=Pθ,Xk=Pθ,{x1,…,xk} and Pθ,n,k=Pθ,Xn,k=Pθ,X∖{xk}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝜃𝑘subscript𝑃𝜃subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑃𝜃subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘 and subscript𝑃𝜃𝑛𝑘subscript𝑃𝜃subscript𝑋𝑛𝑘subscript𝑃𝜃𝑋subscript𝑥𝑘P_{\theta,k}=P_{\theta,X_{k}}=P_{\theta,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}\quad\text{ and }\quad P_{\theta,n,k}=P_{\theta,X_{n,k}}=P_{\theta,X\setminus\{x_{k}\}}

and

sθ,k=sθ,f,Xk=sθ,f,{x1,…,xk} and sθ,n,k=sθ,f,Xn,k=sθ,f,X∖{xk}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝜃𝑘subscript𝑠𝜃𝑓subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑠𝜃𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘 and subscript𝑠𝜃𝑛𝑘subscript𝑠𝜃𝑓subscript𝑋𝑛𝑘subscript𝑠𝜃𝑓𝑋subscript𝑥𝑘s_{\theta,k}=s_{\theta,f,X_{k}}=s_{\theta,f,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}\quad\text{ and }\quad s_{\theta,n,k}=s_{\theta,f,X_{n,k}}=s_{\theta,f,X\setminus\{x_{k}\}}

for k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq n and f𝑓f such that f​(X)=Ym𝑓𝑋subscript𝑌𝑚f(X)=Y_{m}. These notational conventions are reintroduced preceding their use in the proofs.

7.3 Sobolev Spaces

For α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0, the Sobolev space W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) consists of square-integrable functions f:ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} such that

∥f∥W2α​(ℝd)2=∫ℝd(1+∥ξ∥2)α​|f^​(ξ)|2​d⁡ξ<∞.superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑2subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscript1superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜉2𝛼superscript^𝑓𝜉2d𝜉\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}^{2}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}(1+\mathinner{\lVert\xi\rVert}^{2})^{\alpha}\mathinner{\lvert\widehat{f}(\xi)\rvert}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\xi<\infty. (7.7)

The norm of W2α​(Ω)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼ΩW_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) is

∥f∥W2α​(Ω)=inffe∈W2α​(ℝd){∥fe∥W2α​(ℝd):fe|Ω=f}.subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼Ωsubscriptinfimumsubscript𝑓𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑:subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑓𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑evaluated-atsubscript𝑓𝑒Ω𝑓\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega)}=\inf_{f_{e}\in W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\big{\{}\mathinner{\lVert f_{e}\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\,\mathrel{\mathop{\ordinarycolon}}\,f_{e}|_{\Omega}=f\big{\}}. (7.8)

If α∈ℕ0𝛼subscriptℕ0\alpha\in\mathbb{N}_{0}, W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) consists of functions whose weak derivatives up to order α𝛼\alpha exist and are square-integrable. It is a standard result (e.g., Wendland, 2005, Corollary 10.13) that for a kernel K𝐾K which satisfies Assumption 2.2 the RKHS H​(K,ℝd)𝐻𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) is norm-equivalent to W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}). This is to say that H​(K,ℝd)𝐻𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) and W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) are equal as sets and that there are positive constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} such that

C1​∥f∥W2α​(ℝd)≤∥f∥H​(K,ℝd)≤C2​∥f∥W2α​(ℝd)subscript𝐶1subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝐶2subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑C_{1}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d})}\leq C_{2}\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d})}

for every f∈H​(K,ℝd)𝑓𝐻𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑f\in H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}). An analogous result carries over to H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega), which is related to H​(K,ℝd)𝐻𝐾superscriptℝ𝑑H(K,\mathbb{R}^{d}) in the same way as W2α​(Ω)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼ΩW_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) is to W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) via (7.8). We use the following two facts in the proof of Theorem 2.3:

  • •

    Let B𝐵B be any open ball centered at the origin. Then constant functions are contained in W2α​(Ω)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼ΩW_{2}^{\alpha}(\Omega) for any α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 because one can construct a bump function which is constant in B𝐵B and whose Fourier transform decays with a super-algebraic rate.

  • •

    The function ΦΦ\Phi, which defines K𝐾K in Assumption 2.2, is Hölder continuous with the exponent β​(α)=min⁡{1,α−d/2}>0𝛽𝛼1𝛼𝑑20{\beta(\alpha)=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0} on any sufficiently regular domain ΩΩ\Omega (e.g., an open ball). That is, there is a positive constant C𝐶C such that

    |Φ​(0)−Φ​(x)|≤C​∥x∥β​(α)Φ0Φ𝑥𝐶superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝛽𝛼\mathinner{\lvert\Phi(0)-\Phi(x)\rvert}\leq C\mathinner{\lVert x\rVert}^{\beta(\alpha)} (7.9)

    for any x∈Ω𝑥Ωx\in\Omega. This assertion is a consequence of the classical inclusion relation between Sobolev and Hölder spaces (e.g., Triebel, 1978, Remark 2 on p. 206). That ΦΦ\Phi is an element of W2α​(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝑊2𝛼superscriptℝ𝑑W_{2}^{\alpha}(\mathbb{R}^{d}) is easy to verify using (2.9) and (7.7).

7.4 Proof of Theorem 2.3

We split the proof of Theorem 2.3, which is repeated below, in two.

See 2.3

Equation 2.11 is a rather straightforward consequence of (7.4) when one interprets λ𝜆\lambda as a scaling of the covariate set instead of a kernel parameter, while proving Equation 2.12 requires some more work, including upper and lower bounds for the conditional variance. Most of the proof of Equation 2.11 is contained in the following lemmas, which will be used again in Section 7.6.

Lemma 7.1 (Continuity of the data-fit and model complexity)

Suppose that ΦΦ\Phi is continuous and n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1. Then the functions

fdf​(λ)=Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym and fmc​(λ)=log​detKλ​(X,X)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓df𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚 and subscript𝑓mc𝜆subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋f_{\textup{df}}(\lambda)=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}\quad\text{ and }\quad f_{\textup{mc}}(\lambda)=\log\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)

are well-defined and continuous on (0,∞)0(0,\infty).

Proof  Define Xλ={xi/λ}i=1nsubscript𝑋𝜆superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝑖1𝑛X_{\lambda}=\{x_{i}/\lambda\}_{i=1}^{n} and observe that Kλ​(X,X)=K​(Xλ,Xλ)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋𝐾subscript𝑋𝜆subscript𝑋𝜆K_{\lambda}(X,X)=K(X_{\lambda},X_{\lambda}). Since K𝐾K is a positive-definite kernel and the covariates X𝑋X are distinct, this shows that Kλ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋K_{\lambda}(X,X) is positive-definite and hence non-singular for every λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0. In particular, detKλ​(X,X)>0subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋0\det K_{\lambda}(X,X)>0 for every λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 by positive-definiteness. Therefore the functions fdfsubscript𝑓dff_{\textup{df}} and fmcsubscript𝑓mcf_{\textup{mc}} are well-defined. Because K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) is continuous, each element of Kλ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋K_{\lambda}(X,X) is a continuous function of λ𝜆\lambda. From the definition of the determinant it immediately follows that fmcsubscript𝑓mcf_{\textup{mc}} is continuous. The continuity of fdfsubscript𝑓dff_{\textup{df}} is then a consequence of, for example, Cramer’s rule and the positivity of detKλ​(X,X)subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋\det K_{\lambda}(X,X).

Three auxiliary results are needed to prove Equation 2.12. The first of these—or its variants—is well known in scattered data approximation literature (e.g., Schaback, 1995). The version that we need here is contained in the proof of Theorem 4.4 in Karvonen et al. (2020).

Proposition 7.3

Suppose that K𝐾K satisfies Assumption 2.2 and let X={xi}i=1n𝑋superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑛X=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} be any set of distinct points in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. PX​(x)2≥C​∥x−X∥2​α−dsubscript𝑃𝑋superscript𝑥2𝐶superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥𝑋2𝛼𝑑P_{X}(x)^{2}\geq C\mathinner{\lVert x-X\rVert}^{2\alpha-d}

The second auxiliary result, which is standard and essentially Exercise 8.66 in Iske (2018), gives a rough upper bound on the conditional variance under Assumption 2.2.

Proposition 7.4

for a certain positive constant C𝐶C which depends only on ΦΦ\Phi. Using this bound in (7.14) concludes the proof.  

Our third auxiliary result is an expression for the modified log-likelihood function. Although this expression has appeared in the literature (e.g., Xu and Stein, 2017, Section 4.2.2), we have not encountered its proof and therefore provide one based entirely on linear algebra, block matrix inversion, and determinantal identities. The expressions for the individual terms of the modified log-likelihood function are relatively well known. For the data-fit term, see Schaback and Werner (2006, Theorem 6) or Müller (2008, Bemerkung 3.1.4). We also point the reader to Section 3 in Scheuerer (2011). The expression for the model complexity term appear in literature on determinantal point processes (e.g., Bardenet and Hardy, 2020, Section 2.4). For the purposes of this proposition and the proof of Equation 2.12 we use the notation

Pθ,k​(x)=Pθ,{x1,…,xk}​(x) and sθ,k​(x)=sθ,f,{x1,…,xk}​(x)formulae-sequencesubscript𝑃𝜃𝑘𝑥subscript𝑃𝜃subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘𝑥 and subscript𝑠𝜃𝑘𝑥subscript𝑠𝜃𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑘𝑥P_{\theta,k}(x)=P_{\theta,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}(x)\quad\text{ and }\quad s_{\theta,k}(x)=s_{\theta,f,\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}\}}(x)

for k≤n𝑘𝑛k\leq n.

Proposition 7.5

Lemma 7.6

7.5 Proof of Theorem 2.6

See 2.6

Proof  Because the data are m𝑚m-constant, there is a constant function f≡c𝑓𝑐f\equiv c for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R} such that Ym=Y−m​(X)=f​(X)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑌𝑚𝑋𝑓𝑋Y_{m}=Y-m(X)=f(X). Recall from Section 7.3 that Assumption 2.2 implies that f𝑓f is an element of H​(K,B)𝐻𝐾𝐵H(K,B) for an open ball B𝐵B that can be selected such that X⊂B𝑋𝐵X\subset B. Let Xλ={xi/λ}i=1nsubscript𝑋𝜆superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝜆𝑖1𝑛X_{\lambda}=\{x_{i}/\lambda\}_{i=1}^{n} and write

μλ​(x)=m​(x)+sλ​(x)=m​(x)+sf,Xλ​(λ−1​x).subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥𝑚𝑥subscript𝑠𝜆𝑥𝑚𝑥subscript𝑠𝑓subscript𝑋𝜆superscript𝜆1𝑥\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+s_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+s_{f,X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x).

The RKHS error estimate (7.6) yields, for any λ≥1𝜆1\lambda\geq 1,

|m​(x)+c−μλ​(x)|=|f​(λ−1​x)−sf,Xλ​(λ−1​x)|≤∥f∥H​(K,B)​PXλ​(λ−1​x).𝑚𝑥𝑐subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥𝑓superscript𝜆1𝑥subscript𝑠𝑓subscript𝑋𝜆superscript𝜆1𝑥subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻𝐾𝐵subscript𝑃subscript𝑋𝜆superscript𝜆1𝑥\mathinner{\lvert m(x)+c-\mu_{\lambda}(x)\rvert}=\mathinner{\lvert f(\lambda^{-1}x)-s_{f,X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x)\rvert}\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,B)}P_{X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x). (7.19)

As in the proof of Equation 2.12, Proposition 7.4 yields the bound

Pλ​(x)2=PXλ​(λ−1​x)2≤C​λ−β​(α)subscript𝑃𝜆superscript𝑥2subscript𝑃subscript𝑋𝜆superscriptsuperscript𝜆1𝑥2𝐶superscript𝜆𝛽𝛼P_{\lambda}(x)^{2}=P_{X_{\lambda}}(\lambda^{-1}x)^{2}\leq C\lambda^{-\beta(\alpha)} (7.20)

for β=min⁡{1,α−d/2}>0𝛽1𝛼𝑑20\beta=\min\{1,\alpha-d/2\}>0 and a positive constant C𝐶C which does not depend on λ𝜆\lambda. The claim limλ→∞μλ​(x)=m​(x)+csubscript→𝜆subscript𝜇𝜆𝑥𝑚𝑥𝑐\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\mu_{\lambda}(x)=m(x)+c is proved by inserting this bound in (7.19). The claim for the conditional covariance follows from (7.20) and the Cauchy–Schwarz covariance inequality Pλ​(x,y)2≤Pλ​(x)​Pλ​(y)subscript𝑃𝜆superscript𝑥𝑦2subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥subscript𝑃𝜆𝑦P_{\lambda}(x,y)^{2}\leq P_{\lambda}(x)P_{\lambda}(y).  

Remark 7.7

Note in the above proof it is sufficient that Pλ​(x)subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥P_{\lambda}(x) tends to zero as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. Unlike in the proof of Equation 2.12, the rate with which this convergence occurs is of no importance. From the proof of Proposition 7.4 it is easy to see that a sufficient condition for limλ→∞Pλ​(x)=0subscript→𝜆subscript𝑃𝜆𝑥0\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}P_{\lambda}(x)=0 is that K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for a continuous Φ:ℝd→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}. Therefore Theorem 2.6 holds if K𝐾K is a continuous stationary kernel such that constant functions are contained in H​(K,B)𝐻𝐾𝐵H(K,B) for some open ball B𝐵B centered at the origin. This generalisation can be extended also to Equation 2.11 and Theorem 3.1. Further generalisations are discussed in Section 5.

Remark 7.8

Proving that limλ→∞ℓCV​(λ∣Y)=∞subscript→𝜆subscriptℓCVconditional𝜆𝑌\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y)=\infty and λCV<∞subscript𝜆CV\lambda_{\textup{CV}}<\infty if the data are not m𝑚m-constant is more challenging than the same for the maximum likelihood estimate. This is because in the proof of Equation 2.12 one could exploit a recursive form of the modified log-likelihood function that follows from Proposition 7.5 and obtain a closed-form expression for the term in which the conditional mean and variance are based on one data point. If n>2𝑛2n>2, it is more difficult to analyse any of the analogous terms in ℓCV​(λ∣Y)subscriptℓCVconditional𝜆𝑌\ell_{\textup{CV}}(\lambda\mid Y) because each of these terms is built out of conditional moments based on n−1𝑛1n-1 points.

Proof  The modified log-likelihood function is

7.8 Proof of Theorem 5.2

We begin with a technical lemma which is used to establish some properties of the information functionals.

The following proposition is a generalisation of the minimum-norm property for interpolation based on point evaluations that was reviewed in Section 7.1. We have not been able to locate a convenient reference and therefore provide a proof.

Proposition 7.10

Let K𝐾K be a positive-definite kernel on a set ΩΩ\Omega. If f∈H​(K,Ω)𝑓𝐻𝐾Ωf\in H(K,\Omega), then

ℐ​(f)𝖳​K​(ℐ,ℐ)−1​ℐ​(f)≤∥f∥H​(K,Ω)2ℐsuperscript𝑓𝖳𝐾superscriptℐℐ1ℐ𝑓superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑓𝐻𝐾Ω2\mathcal{I}(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f)\leq\mathinner{\lVert f\rVert}_{H(K,\Omega)}^{2} (7.25)

for every n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 and every collection ℐ={I1,…,In}ℐsubscript𝐼1…subscript𝐼𝑛\mathcal{I}=\{I_{1},\ldots,I_{n}\} of n𝑛n non-trivial linear functionals which are linearly independent and bounded on H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega).

Proof  Let sℐ​fsubscript𝑠ℐ𝑓s_{\mathcal{I}}f be the minimum-norm interpolant to f𝑓f in H​(K,Ω)𝐻𝐾ΩH(K,\Omega), which is to say that

By, for example, Theorem 16.1 in Wendland (2005) or Section 3.3 in Oettershagen (2017) this interpolant is unique and has the explicit form

(sℐ​f)​(x)=I​(f)𝖳​K​(ℐ,ℐ)−1​K​(ℐ,x)=∑i=1nIiy​(K​(x,y))​(K​(ℐ,ℐ)−1​ℐ​(f))i.subscript𝑠ℐ𝑓𝑥𝐼superscript𝑓𝖳𝐾superscriptℐℐ1𝐾ℐ𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑖𝑦𝐾𝑥𝑦subscript𝐾superscriptℐℐ1ℐ𝑓𝑖(s_{\mathcal{I}}f)(x)=I(f)^{\mathsf{T}}K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}K(\mathcal{I},x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}I_{i}^{y}(K(x,y))(K(\mathcal{I},\mathcal{I})^{-1}\mathcal{I}(f))_{i}.

7.10 Proof of Theorem 5.4

Let d=1𝑑1d=1 and K​(x,y)=Φ​(x−y)𝐾𝑥𝑦Φ𝑥𝑦K(x,y)=\Phi(x-y) for an integrable function Φ:ℝ→ℝ:Φ→ℝℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} that is infinitely differentiable in a neighbourhood of the origin. Define the diagonal matrix

Δλ=diag​(1,λ−1,…,λn−1)subscriptΔ𝜆diag1superscript𝜆1…superscript𝜆𝑛1\Delta_{\lambda}=\mathrm{diag}(1,\lambda^{-1},\ldots,\lambda^{n-1})

and the Vandermonde matrix

V​(X)=(1x1⋯x1n−1⋮⋮⋱⋮1xn⋯xnn−1).𝑉𝑋matrix1subscript𝑥1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑛1⋮⋮⋱⋮1subscript𝑥𝑛⋯superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑛1V(X)=\begin{pmatrix}1&x_{1}&\cdots&x_{1}^{n-1}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ 1&x_{n}&\cdots&x_{n}^{n-1}\end{pmatrix}.

It is a standard result in polynomial interpolation that the Vandermonde matrix is non-singular when xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} are distinct. Recall that W𝑊W is the Wronskian defined in (5.11). The Wronskian is non-singular if the Fourier transform of ΦΦ\Phi is positive (Lee et al., 2007, Lemma 3.3). To see this, note first that

(−1)j(−i)i+j∂i+j∂vi​∂wjK(v,w)|v=0w=0=(−i)i+jΦ(i+j)(0)=12​π∫ℝξi+jΦ^(ξ)dξ(-1)^{j}(-\mathrm{i})^{i+j}\frac{\partial^{i+j}}{\partial v^{i}\partial w^{j}}K(v,w)\Bigl{|}_{\begin{subarray}{c}v=0\\ w=0\end{subarray}}=(-\mathrm{i})^{i+j}\Phi^{(i+j)}(0)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{\mathbb{R}}\xi^{i+j}\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\operatorname{d\!}\xi

and observe then that

∑i=0n−1∑j=0n−1ai​aj​Φ(i+j)​(0)=12​π​∫ℝΦ^​(ξ)​(∑i=1nai​ξi)2​d⁡ξsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑛1subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑎𝑗superscriptΦ𝑖𝑗012𝜋subscriptℝ^Φ𝜉superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖superscript𝜉𝑖2d𝜉\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}a_{i}a_{j}\Phi^{(i+j)}(0)=\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{\mathbb{R}}\widehat{\Phi}(\xi)\Bigg{(}\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\xi^{i}\Bigg{)}^{2}\operatorname{d\!}\xi

is positive for any n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} and any non-zero a=(a0,…,an−1)∈ℝn𝑎subscript𝑎0…subscript𝑎𝑛1superscriptℝ𝑛a=(a_{0},\ldots,a_{n-1})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. It follows from these equations that the Wronskian is non-singular because it can be written as a product of a positive-definite matrix with elements Φ(i+j)​(0)superscriptΦ𝑖𝑗0\Phi^{(i+j)}(0) and two non-singular diagonal matrices.

Proof  We proceed as in the proof of Equation 2.11 in Section 7.4 and conclude that to prove the claim it is sufficient to show that the limit limλ→∞Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ymsubscript→𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚\lim_{\lambda\to\infty}Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m} exists and is finite. Kλ​(X,X)=V​(X)​Δλ​W​Δλ​V​(X)𝖳+λ−n​[V​(X)​Δλ​W1,λ+W2,λ​Δλ​V​(X)𝖳]+λ−2​n​W3,λ,subscript𝐾𝜆𝑋𝑋𝑉𝑋subscriptΔ𝜆𝑊subscriptΔ𝜆𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳superscript𝜆𝑛delimited-[]𝑉𝑋subscriptΔ𝜆subscript𝑊1𝜆subscript𝑊2𝜆subscriptΔ𝜆𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳superscript𝜆2𝑛subscript𝑊3𝜆K_{\lambda}(X,X)=V(X)\Delta_{\lambda}W\Delta_{\lambda}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}+\lambda^{-n}\big{[}V(X)\Delta_{\lambda}W_{1,\lambda}+W_{2,\lambda}\Delta_{\lambda}V(X)^{\mathsf{T}}\big{]}+\lambda^{-2n}W_{3,\lambda},

where the matrices W1,λsubscript𝑊1𝜆W_{1,\lambda}, W2,λsubscript𝑊2𝜆W_{2,\lambda}, and W3,λsubscript𝑊3𝜆W_{3,\lambda} are bounded as λ→∞→𝜆\lambda\to\infty. We may now use this equation to write

Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym=Ym𝖳​V​(X)−𝖳​Δλ−1​(W+Aλ)−1​Δλ−1​V​(X)−1​Ym,superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1superscript𝑊subscript𝐴𝜆1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1𝑉superscript𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}(W+A_{\lambda})^{-1}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}, (7.28)

where

Aλ=λ−n​[W1,λ​V​(X)−𝖳​Δλ−1+Δλ−1​V​(X)−1​W2,λ]+λ−2​n​Δλ−1​V​(X)−1​W3,λ​V​(X)−𝖳​Δλ−1.subscript𝐴𝜆superscript𝜆𝑛delimited-[]subscript𝑊1𝜆𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1𝑉superscript𝑋1subscript𝑊2𝜆superscript𝜆2𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1𝑉superscript𝑋1subscript𝑊3𝜆𝑉superscript𝑋𝖳superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1A_{\lambda}=\lambda^{-n}\big{[}W_{1,\lambda}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}+\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}W_{2,\lambda}\big{]}+\lambda^{-2n}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}W_{3,\lambda}V(X)^{-\mathsf{T}}\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}.

Since Δλ−1=𝒪​(λn−1)superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1𝒪superscript𝜆𝑛1\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}(\lambda^{n-1}), we conclude that Aλ=𝒪​(λ−1)subscript𝐴𝜆𝒪superscript𝜆1A_{\lambda}=\mathcal{O}(\lambda^{-1}). Furthermore, from the assumption that Ym=(c,…,c)subscript𝑌𝑚𝑐…𝑐Y_{m}=(c,\ldots,c) for some c∈ℝ𝑐ℝc\in\mathbb{R} it follows that V​(X)−1​Ym=(c,0,…,0)∈ℝn𝑉superscript𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚𝑐0…0superscriptℝ𝑛V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}=(c,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}. Consequently, Δλ−1​V​(X)−1​Ym=(c,0,…,0)=D0superscriptsubscriptΔ𝜆1𝑉superscript𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚𝑐0…0subscript𝐷0\Delta_{\lambda}^{-1}V(X)^{-1}Y_{m}=(c,0,\ldots,0)=D_{0}. Therefore (7.28) yields

Ym𝖳​Kλ​(X,X)−1​Ym=D0𝖳​(W+Aλ)−1​D0→D0𝖳​W−1​D0<∞ as λ→∞,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑌𝑚𝖳subscript𝐾𝜆superscript𝑋𝑋1subscript𝑌𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐷0𝖳superscript𝑊subscript𝐴𝜆1subscript𝐷0→superscriptsubscript𝐷0𝖳superscript𝑊1subscript𝐷0→ as 𝜆Y_{m}^{\mathsf{T}}K_{\lambda}(X,X)^{-1}Y_{m}=D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}(W+A_{\lambda})^{-1}D_{0}\to D_{0}^{\mathsf{T}}W^{-1}D_{0}<\infty\quad\text{ as }\quad\lambda\to\infty,

where the Wronskian W𝑊W is, as noted earlier, non-singular.
